play.title: The Life of Timon of Athens

persona.persdescription: Timon of Athens is a rich man of Athens with absolutely no sense of scale, either in prosperity or in misery. He believes that one can buy friendship, and showers rich gifts on anybody who attends his feasts — and anybody can simply walk in off the street to join them. His chief fault is his generosity and his belief in the goodness of man; he refuses to look at his accounts because he trusts that his steward, Flavius, is honest. He refuses to see debts to him repaid, and is convinced that anyone he has been kind to will naturally return the favor. An open and honest man, he has no understanding of hypocrisy and therefore no defense against flattery, which he takes at face value because he himself means everything he says. The discovery that he has managed to spend his entire fortune startles him, but it is not until nobody will help that he becomes disturbed. Harassed by creditors, he gives way to anger soon becoming as extravagant in his hatred for those who have disappointed him as he was in his gifts to them. He thereafter refuses to see any good in humanity and spends most of his time cursing it. He goes to live in a cave, and when he accidentally digs up a hidden pile of gold, he gives it to soldiers planning to sack Athens, to prostitutes and thieves, enjoining them to continue in their acts and grow worse at them until the entire world is destroyed. Finally dying, and as happy to do so as he is capable of being happy, he writes his own epitaph, a final insult to the whole of humanity — a curious conflation of the two parts of his personality, both requesting anonymity and making sure passers-by know his name.

Alcibiades is a young Athenian captain, a great soldier who has won many victories for Athens. He best loves war, but he is a true friend of Timon’s and a generous man. He attempts to save the life of one of his soldiers who in a temper killed another man, but is unsuccessful before the Senate of old, unyielding men. He is angered that they will not take his past services into account when he pleads with them, and rashly suggests that they are growing forgetful, leaving him exiled. He then rejoins his army, intent on conquering Athens in revenge. He is extremely proud and looks down on the senators as a pack of usurers. Horrified at how hard Timon has fallen, he attempts to help him, but is rebuffed. He uses Timon’s name as an excuse in his propaganda, and hopes to bring him onto his side just as the senators hope to, but his messenger arrives too late. He is threatening enough that the senators crumble and simply hand Athens over to him without fighting, and then magnanimous, as they were not. Alcibiades has a very simple view of the world, and within that view is an upright and decent man, is somewhat reckless.

Apemantus is a professional cynic, a snarling, nasty man who insults everybody he meets without appearing to derive any pleasure from doing so. He sees through flattery and refuses gifts from Timon, eating only poorly at his table. Though he pretends to like nobody, Apemantus strives to make Timon realize just how foolishly he is acting, but does not give his advice in the most diplomatic manner. When Timon loses all his wealth and becomes a misanthrope in the forest, it becomes evident that Apemantus is something of a poseur, who does not appreciate the fact that someone is stealing his role. Even though he claims to love no-one but himself, Apemantus still tries to feed Timon in the forest, only to be rejected by a man who now hates humanity even more than he does himself. The discovery that it is possible to be even nastier than he is enrages Apemantus, who tells everybody that Timon has found some gold so that he will be beset by visitors.

Caphis is the servant of a Senator who also dabbles in usury and has lent Timon a great deal of money. He is sent to obtain repayment, but is put off for an entire month by Flavius, until Caphis finally presents his bill to Timon directly, in the public street. He does not much like the task of asking a man for money, but holds his ground and refuses to be delayed any further.
Cupid is one of the Ladies who come to present a masque of the five senses at Timon’s feast, and explains the idea to Timon.

The First Bandit does not see why a ruined man should be left any money at all, but insists he is not a thief. He realizes that Timon’s advice to continue stealing is not given out of kindness, but thinks that there’s no point in giving up robbery while there’s a war on.

The Second Bandit has heard that Timon has some treasure on him and brings his fellows to find him, but insists that he is not a thief. Timon’s advice to continue thieving is so nasty that he decides to turn honest.
The Third Bandit has seen Timon before; like his fellows, he insists that he is not a thief. Timon’s advice to continue stealing is so nasty it almost convinces him to give up his job as a robber.
First Lady Amazon Masker is one of the Ladies who come to present a masque of the five senses at Timon’s feast, and disclaims his praise.
Lady Amazon Maskers [mute roles] are a group of women who come to present a masque of the five senses at Timon’s feast.

The First Lord is an Athenian gentleman, one of Timon’s innumerable bootlickers, who thinks nothing of simply walking off the street to eat at Timon’s table and receiving rich gifts from him with no more repayment than flattery. He refuses to help Timon out in his need, claiming to have no money on hand at the time, and is shocked at Timon’s reaction. A fatuous, greedy, and rather silly fellow, he fails to see the problem in refusing to help Timon while still wearing a jewel the latter gave him in his cap when visiting him.

The Second Lord is an Athenian gentleman, one of Timon’s innumerable bootlickers, who thinks nothing of simply walking off the street to eat at Timon’s table and receiving rich gifts from him with no more repayment than flattery. He refuses to help Timon out in his need, claiming to have no money on hand at the time, and is shocked at Timon’s reaction. He is fatuous and greedy, though unlike some of the other lords, he does show some (extremely faint) concern for Timon’s mental state. He is also aware that Timon’s fortune will not last, and that therefore one had best make the best use of it while one can.

The Third Lord is one of Timon’s innumerable bootlickers, who refuses to help him out when he is in need and is shocked at Timon’s reaction. He is aware that Timon’s fortunes cannot last and that therefore one had best make use of it while one can. A gossip, he is less concerned about Timon’s mental state than about the state of his own hat.

The Fourth Lord is one of Timon’s innumerable bootlickers, who refuses to help him out when he is in need and is shocked at Timon’s reaction. He is completely oblivious to the fact that Timon has some reason to be ticked off at his so-called friends.

The First Senator is an old man, one of the members of government who refuses to help Timon when he is in need. He also offers windy reasons for applying laws strictly without mitigation, without considering greater concerns. His ill-considered exiling of Alcibiades puts all of Athens in danger. Due to this he is forced to plead with Timon for help against Alcibiades when the panic-struck Athenians want Timon as a dictator to save them from the rebels. He is unsuccessful. In the end he surrenders to Alcibiades to save the city.

The Second Senator is an old man, one of the members of government who refuses to help Timon when he is in need, and refuses to pay any attention to Alcibiades’s pleas for one of his men’s life. As a result, he is forced to plead with Timon for help against Alcibiades when the panic-struck Athenians want Timon as a dictator to save them from the rebels. He is unsuccessful. In the end he surrenders to Alcibiades to save the city.

The Third Senator practices usury on the side, and is deeply concerned about how much money Timon spends. Realizing that Timon’s endless parties can only result in his bankruptcy, he decides to call in his debts while Timon may still have some money left to pay them back, setting off the collapse of Timon’s credit. He is shocked at Alcibiades’s suggestion that he and the other old senators are growing forgetful. He is terrified of the arrival of the exile’s army.
The Fourth Senator is terrified of the arrival of Alcibiades’s army.

The First Stranger has his ear to the ground and knows what is happening to Timon’s fortunes before some of Timon’s supposed friends do. He is shocked that Lucius refuses to help the other man, and swears that had he been as well used by Timon as Lucius had, he would have helped.
The Second Stranger (Hostilius) is shocked that Lucullus has refused to help Timon out, and gossips to Lucius about it. He takes Lucius’s measure when the latter also refuses to help.
The Third Stranger is appalled at Lucius’s refusal to help Timon.

Flaminius is one of Timon’s servants, sent to request fifty talents from Lucullus when Timon’s debts catch up with him. An honest man, he refuses to be bribed, and is horrified at Lucullus’s refusal to help Timon. He tries to keep Timon away from direct contact with his creditors’ servants, but is unsuccessful. He brings Lucullus’s invitation to a hunting party to Timon, along with some hunting greyhounds.

Flavius is Timon’s Steward, and the head of his household, and the man best aware of just how much his master spends. The state of Timon’s accounts brings him to despair, as does his inability to get Timon to understand that he is essentially bankrupt and that giving costly presents to anyone who shows up for dinner is not really an option. Timon’s last barrier against his creditors, he is forever putting off the debt collectors while he tries to find the money to pay them back and get it through Timon’s thick skull that he is in serious financial trouble. He even goes so far as to ask the Senate for help in Timon’s name without being asked to; due to their refusal, he is skeptical of Timon’s belief that his friends will help him. Flavius dearly loves his master and is deeply loyal to him. When the money finally runs entirely out and Timon leaves Athens, Flavius gives what he has to his fellow servants and goes off to find his vanished master. This ends up making his fortune, but does not make him happy. Easily moved to tears, Flavius admires goodness and is rather depressed by how little there is of it in the world. He leads the Senators to Timon’s cave for the sake of Athens, but has no great hope of their success.

A Fool speaks truth in riddles, and has a good mocking tongue. He is not afraid of criticizing his mistress behind her back. Though he insults people, he appears downright kind when he is in Apemantus’s company.

Hortensius is the servant of one of Timon’s creditors, sent to recover a debt. He does not like his task, given that he is fully aware that Timon has given his master gifts worth far more than the borrowed sum. He attempts to do the job all the same, but soon realizes that the odds of getting any money back are rather low, and that Timon is no longer entirely sane.
Isidore’s Servant is the servant of a usurer to whom Timon owes a great deal of money. He is sent to recover the sum from Timon, but is unable to get past Flavius, who puts him off time and again.
A Jeweller [possibly named Titus] is a flattering man who brings Timon a jewel, knowing that the latter will buy it no matter the cost.

Lucilius is one of Timon’s servants, a younger man who has served his master well for some years now. One of his tasks is serving at table. He is in love with the Old Athenian’s daughter, and visits her at night. His fortune is made when Timon finds out that the Old Athenian disapproves of the match because of Lucilius’s poverty; Timon proceeds to enrich him. He is suitably grateful.

Lucius is a lord of Athens, one of Timon’s flattering friends who is only generous to rich people. Quite shamelessly hypocritical, he refuses to help Timon in his need by pretending not to have enough money on him, even though he has just accuses everybody else who refused to help false friends. He then has the audacity to send his servant to ask for repayment of an earlier loan.

Lucius’s Servant is sent by his master to recover some money from Timon, and is well aware that the man is essentially bankrupt. He finds his task, and that of the various other servants on similar errands, rather unethical, as Timon has spent more on the various creditors than he has borrowed from them. Nevertheless, he does his best to get the money back.

Lucullus is a lord of Athens, one of Timon’s flattering and not particularly generous friends, though he does send him some hunting hounds when he invites Timon to hunt with him. He is a sleazy flatterer who attempts to get out of helping Timon by bribing Flaminius to say he didn’t see him. He lets himself off the hook by claiming to have warned Timon to be a bit more careful with his money.
Lucullus’s Servant is trusted by his master, but not so much that Lucullus will attempt to offer a bribe in his presence.
A Merchant is a flattering man who attends Timon’s feast and is well aware of what Apemantus is like.
A Messenger informs the Senate of just how bad the situation with Alcibiades’s approaching army is, and also informs them that Alcibiades too is seeking Timon’s support.
A Messenger from Ventidius comes to beg Timon to pay off the debt when Ventidius is arrested for non-repayment of five talents, a huge sum.

An Old Athenian is a rich, upright, honorable and crusty old man with a healthy respect for his own position in life. Insistent that his only daughter shall marry a rich man to match his own position, he loves her enough to swear to disown her if she marries Lucilius, a mere servant. He is however perfectly happy to accept the young man as his son-in-law once Timon enriches him.

A Painter is a starving artist in need of patronage who, along with his fellow crawler the Poet, hopes to get money off Timon by flattering him. He cannot decide whether to be self-deprecating about his art or not, and is rather affected about his calling. He is also quite open about the financial realities of life and the need to sell oneself — at least to other artists. The moment he hears that the ruined Timon has found gold, he runs to try his old tricks and get some money off of him, hypocritically swearing that he has come to visit simply out of friendship — with unexpected results, though he does get some gold out of it.
Philotus is the servant of one of Timon’s creditors, sent to recover the debt, though he has little hope of doing so.

Phrynia is one of Alcibiades’s mistresses, accompanying him and his army as he marches on Athens. Timon accuses her of being a prostitute riddled with venereal disease, and she insults him back, but is willing to listen to his cursing so long as he gives her gold.

A Poet is a verse-maker who lives by acquiring the support (and therefore money) of rich men whom he praises in his poems. Somewhat wiser to the ways of the world than his companion crawler the Painter, he attempts to warn Timon of the possibility that his luck might not hold and that his so-call friends are not true ones. Affected and afflicted by false modesty, he pretends not to work at his poetry and that what he produces is merely trifles, though he clearly hopes they will be taken otherwise. The moment he hears that the ruined Timon has found gold, he runs to try his old tricks and get some money off of him, hypocritically swearing that he has come to visit simply out of friendship — with unexpected results, though he does get some gold out of it.

Sempronius is a lord of Athens, one of Timon’s flattering friends, and a very proud man who considers himself insulted to be asked for help after others instead of first. Or, at least, that’s his excuse for not helping Timon in his need.

Servilius is one of Timon’s servants, sent to request fifty talents from Lucius when Timon’s debts catch up with him. He appears to accept Lucius’s word that he doesn’t have enough money on him to help out. He announces to Timon that Lucius has sent him some horses and he also announces the arrival of some Senators at Timon’s feast.

A Soldier is sent by Alcibiades to find Timon and ask for his support in his attack on Athens, but only finds Timon’s grave. He is illiterate, but knows the value of words, and brings a cast of the inscription on the tomb to his general.

Timandra is one of Alcibiades’s mistresses, accompanying him and his army as he marches on Athens. She has heard of Timon, who accuses her of being riddled with venereal disease. Though insulted by him, she is willing to listen to his cursing so long as he gives her gold.

Timon’s Page is sent to bring two letters, one to Timon and one to Alcibiades. As he cannot read, he mixes the two up and is forced to ask Apemantus for help. He stands up reasonably well to the cynic’s insults.
Timon’s Servant is sent to request fifty talents of Sempronius when Timon’s debts catch up with him. He is appalled when Sempronius refuses to help his master.

Titus is the servant of one of Timon’s creditors, sent to ask for repayment on that debt. He is rather skeptical about the whole process, being quite aware that Timon has spent more on the various creditors than they have lent to him, and does not mind pointing this out. Nevertheless, he does his best to do his job.

Varro’s First Servant works for a usurer to whom Timon owes a great deal of money (3,000 crowns), who is sent to recover a sum that’s been due for six weeks. He makes a weak attempt to match wits with the Fool, and knows quite well what is likely to happen if Apemantus starts to speak. Sent back with a second servant when he fails to get the money back, he is aware of the unfairness of what is happening to Timon. He is not overly fond of his master.

Varro’s Second Servant works for a usurer to whom Timon owes a great deal of money (3,000 crowns), and is sent along with Varro’s First Servant to recover the sum when the latter is unsuccessful in getting the money back on his own. He is not particularly sympathetic to the out-of-work Flavius.

Ventidius is a friend of Timon’s who tends to live beyond his means, to the extent that he ends up in prison for debt. Luckily for him, Timon is foolishly generous and immediately pays the debt. Inheriting his father’s wealth, he does offer to repay this one debt, but may not be particularly surprised when Timon refuses to take them. Growing less foolish with his money after he is rich, he declines to help Timon in his need.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A hall in Timon’s house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, Senators, Lord Timon, Messenger, Lucilius, Servants, Old Athenian, Apemantus, Messenger from Ventidius, Alcibiades, Lords)
scene.scenedescription: A poet and a painter, waiting at Timon’s house to suck up to him, comment to each other on Timon’s generosity. They flatter each other over the mutual excellence of what they plan to offer to him. Timonwalks by, followed by the Senators of Athens. The poet notes that his poem warns Timon that Fortune may turn against him some day. Timon pays out bail money for a friend, enriches one of his servants so that he can marry a rich man’s daughter, and accepts the gifts brought to him. The snarling cynic Apemantus comes in and rails at all of Timon’s suitors, believe all Athenians to be knaves and accusing the poet of being nothing but a flatterer, but Timon pays him little attention. Alcibiades arrives with a group of friends, who are all invited to join in at Timon’s feast. They all go in. Two lords, arriving late, have to deal with Apemantus before going in.
scene.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, at several doors.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Good day, sir.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: I am glad y’ are well.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: I have not seen you long, how goes the world?

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: It wears, sir, as it grows.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Ay, that’s well known;
But what particular rarity? What strange,
Which manifold record not matches? See,
Magic of bounty! All these spirits thy power
Hath conjur’d to attend. I know the merchant.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: I know them both; th’ other’s a jeweller.

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: O, ’tis a worthy lord.

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: Nay, that’s most fix’d.

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: A most incomparable man, breath’d, as it were,
To an untirable and continuate goodness;
He passes.

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: I have a jewel here—

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: O, pray let’s see’t. For the Lord Timon, sir?

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: If he will touch the estimate. But for that—

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: “When we for recompense have prais’d the vild,
It stains the glory in that happy verse
Which aptly sings the good.”

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: ’Tis a good form.

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: And rich. Here is a water, look ye.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication
To the great lord.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: A thing slipp’d idlely from me.
Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes
From whence ’tis nourish’d. The fire i’ th’ flint
Shows not till it be strook; our gentle flame
Provokes itself and like the current flies
Each bound it chases. What have you there?

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.
Let’s see your piece.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: ’Tis a good piece.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: So ’tis. This comes off well and excellent.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Indifferent.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Admirable! How this grace
Speaks his own standing! What a mental power
This eye shoots forth! How big imagination
Moves in this lip! To th’ dumbness of the gesture
One might interpret.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: It is a pretty mocking of the life.
Here is a touch; is’t good?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: I will say of it,
It tutors nature. Artificial strife
Lives in these touches, livelier than life.

scene.stagedir: Enter certain Senators and pass over.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: How this lord is followed!

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: The senators of Athens, happy men!

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Look, more!

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors.
I have, in this rough work, shap’d out a man
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug
With amplest entertainment. My free drift
Halts not particularly, but moves itself
In a wide sea of wax; no levell’d malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold,
But flies an eagle flight, bold, and forth on,
Leaving no tract behind.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: How shall I understand you?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: I will unbolt to you.
You see how all conditions, how all minds,
As well of glib and slipp’ry creatures as
Of grave and austere quality, tender down
Their services to Lord Timon. His large fortune,
Upon his good and gracious nature hanging,
Subdues and properties to his love and tendance
All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-fac’d flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loves better
Than to abhor himself; even he drops down
The knee before him, and returns in peace
Most rich in Timon’s nod.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: I saw them speak together.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill
Feign’d Fortune to be thron’d. The base o’ th’ mount
Is rank’d with all deserts, all kind of natures,
That labor on the bosom of this sphere
To propagate their states. Amongst them all,
Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix’d,
One do I personate of Lord Timon’s frame,
Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her,
Whose present grace to present slaves and servants
Translates his rivals.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: ’Tis conceiv’d to scope.
This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,
With one man beckon’d from the rest below,
Bowing his head against the steepy mount
To climb his happiness, would be well express’d
In our condition.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Nay, sir, but hear me on:
All those which were his fellows but of late—
Some better than his value—on the moment
Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,
Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,
Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him
Drink the free air.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Ay, marry, what of these?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants
Which labor’d after him to the mountain’s top
Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: ’Tis common:
A thousand moral paintings I can show
That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune’s
More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well
To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen
The foot above the head.

scene.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter Lord Timon, addressing himself courteously to every suitor, a Messenger from Ventidius talking with him; Lucilius and other Servants following.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Imprison’d is he, say you?

speech.speaker: MESS. VENT.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord, five talents is his debt,
His means most short, his creditors most strait.
Your honorable letter he desires
To those have shut him up, which failing,
Periods his comfort.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Noble Ventidius! Well;
I am not of that feather to shake off
My friend when he must need me. I do know him
A gentleman that well deserves a help,
Which he shall have. I’ll pay the debt and free him.

speech.speaker: MESS. VENT.
speech.line: Your lordship ever binds him.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Commend me to him. I will send his ransom,
And being enfranchis’d, bid him come to me;
’Tis not enough to help the feeble up,
But to support him after. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: MESS. VENT.
speech.line: All happiness to your honor!

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Freely, good father.

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: Thou hast a servant nam’d Lucilius.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I have so. What of him?

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: Here, at your lordship’s service.

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,
By night frequents my house. I am a man
That from my first have been inclin’d to thrift,
And my estate deserves an heir more rais’d
Than one which holds a trencher.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Well; what further?

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: One only daughter have I, no kin else,
On whom I may confer what I have got.
The maid is fair, a’ th’ youngest for a bride,
And I have bred her at my dearest cost
In qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her love. I prithee, noble lord,
Join with me to forbid him her resort,
Myself have spoke in vain.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: The man is honest.

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: Therefore he will be, Timon.
His honesty rewards him in itself,
It must not bear my daughter.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Does she love him?

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: She is young and apt.
Our own precedent passions do instruct us
What levity’s in youth.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Love you the maid?

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: If in her marriage my consent be missing,
I call the gods to witness, I will choose
Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,
And dispossess her all.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: How shall she be endowed,
If she be mated with an equal husband?

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: This gentleman of mine hath serv’d me long;
To build his fortune I will strain a little,
For ’tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter;
What you bestow, in him I’ll counterpoise,
And make him weigh with her.

speech.speaker: OLD ATH.
speech.line: Most noble lord,
Pawn me to this your honor, she is his.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: My hand to thee, mine honor on my promise.

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: Humbly I thank your lordship. Never may
That state or fortune fall into my keeping,
Which is not owed to you!

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Vouchsafe my labor, and long live your lordship!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I thank you, you shall hear from me anon.
Go not away. What have you there, my friend?

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: A piece of painting, which I do beseech
Your lordship to accept.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Painting is welcome.
The painting is almost the natural man;
For since dishonor traffics with man’s nature,
He is but outside; these pencill’d figures are
Even such as they give out. I like your work,
And you shall find I like it. Wait attendance
Till you hear further from me.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: The gods preserve ye!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Well fare you, gentleman; give me your hand,
We must needs dine together.—Sir, your jewel
Hath suffered under praise.

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: What, my lord, dispraise?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: A mere saciety of commendations;
If I should pay you for’t as ’tis extoll’d,
It would unclew me quite.

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: My lord, ’tis rated
As those which sell would give; but you well know,
Things of like value differing in the owners
Are prized by their masters. Believe’t, dear lord,
You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Well mock’d.

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: No, my good lord, he speaks the common tongue
Which all men speak with him.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Look who comes here; will you be chid?

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: We’ll bear, with your lordship.

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: He’ll spare none.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow—
When thou art Timon’s dog, and these knaves honest.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Why dost thou call them knaves? Thou know’st them not.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Are they not Athenians?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Then I repent not.

speech.speaker: JEW.
speech.line: You know me, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thou know’st I do, I call’d thee by thy name.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Whither art going?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: To knock out an honest Athenian’s brains.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: That’s a deed thou’t die for.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Right, if doing nothing be death by th’ law.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: How lik’st thou this picture, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: The best, for the innocence.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Wrought he not well that painted it?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: He wrought better that made the painter, and yet he’s but a filthy piece of work.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Y’ are a dog.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thy mother’s of my generation; what’s she, if I be a dog?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: No; I eat not lords.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: And thou shouldst, thou’dst anger ladies.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: That’s a lascivious apprehension.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: So thou apprehend’st it, take it for thy labor.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cast a man a doit.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What dost thou think ’tis worth?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: How now, philosopher?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thou liest.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Art not one?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Then I lie not.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Art not a poet?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou hast feign’d him a worthy fellow.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: That’s not feign’d, he is so.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy labor. He that loves to be flatter’d is worthy o’ th’ flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: E’en as Apemantus does now: hate a lord with my heart.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What, thyself?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Wherefore?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: That I had no angry wit to be a lord. Art not thou a merchant?

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: Ay, Apemantus.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

speech.speaker: MER.
speech.line: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Traffic’s thy god, and thy god confound thee!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What trumpet’s that?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: ’Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,
All of companionship.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Pray entertain them, give them guide to us.
You must needs dine with me; go not you hence
Till I have thank’d you. When dinner’s done,
Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights.
Most welcome, sir!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: So, so; there!
Aches contract and starve your supple joints!
That there should be small love amongest these sweet knaves,
And all this courtesy! The strain of man’s bred out
Into baboon and monkey.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Sir, you have sav’d my longing, and I feed
Most hungerly on your sight.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Right welcome, sir!
Ere we depart, we’ll share a bounteous time
In different pleasures. Pray you let us in.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: What time a’ day is’t, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Time to be honest.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: That time serves still.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: The most accursed thou, that still omit’st it.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Thou art going to Lord Timon’s feast?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ay, to see meat fill knaves, and wine heat fools.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Why, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to give thee none.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Hang thyself!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding; make thy requests to thy friend.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I’ll spurn thee hence!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I will fly, like a dog, the heels a’ th’ ass.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: He’s opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in
And taste Lord Timon’s bounty? He outgoes
The very heart of kindness.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: He pours it out: Plutus, the god of gold,
Is but his steward. No meed but he repays
Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him
But breeds the giver a return exceeding
All use of quittance.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: The noblest mind he carries
That ever govern’d man.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: I’ll keep you company.

scene.scenepersonae: (Flavius, Lord Timon, States, Athenian Lords, Alcibiades, Ventidius, Apemantus, Servants, Cupid, Ladies)
scene.scenedescription: At a feast of Timon’s, Ventidius, who was freed from jail thanks to Timon’s generosity, has inherited from his father and tries to pay Timon back. Timon refuses to hear of it. Apemantus too is present; Timon welcomes him but the cynic insists he only wants to be kicked out. Timon rolls his eyes and pays him no heed, letting him have a table by himself, from where he comments bitterly on all that follows. Timon gives a speech in praise of friendship. Some ladies come in to present a masque to Timon. Timon sends his steward Flavius to fetch a casket of jewels for him to distribute. Flavius is worried that Timon’s generosity is bankrupting him. He tries to tell his master this, but Timon doesn’t want to hear of anything concerning him. Presents from Lords Lucullus and Lucius and announced to Timon. Flavius complains to himself that Timon refuses to know what the state of his finances is, and thus doesn’t know that he has no money left. Timon bids farewell to his guests, giving them anything they’ve ever said they liked. Timon tells Apemantus that he’d be good to him as well if he were only a bit nicer, but Apemantus refuses to be bribed into silence; Timon refuses to listen to him when he begins to rail against the high life.
scene.stagedir: Hoboys playing loud music. A great banquet serv’d in, Flavius and others attending; and then enter Lord Timon, the States, the Athenian Lords, Alcibiades, and Ventidius, which Timon redeem’d from prison. Then comes, dropping after all, Apemantus, discontentedly, like himself.

speech.speaker: VEN.
speech.line: Most honored Timon,
It hath pleas’d the gods to remember my father’s age,
And call him to long peace.
He is gone happy, and has left me rich.
Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound
To your free heart, I do return those talents,
Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help
I deriv’d liberty.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: O, by no means,
Honest Ventidius. You mistake my love;
I gave it freely ever, and there’s none
Can truly say he gives if he receives.
If our betters play at that game, we must not dare
To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

speech.speaker: VEN.
speech.line: A noble spirit!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Nay, my lords,
Ceremony was but devis’d at first
To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodness, sorry ere ’tis shown;
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Pray sit, more welcome are ye to my fortunes
Than my fortunes to me.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: My lord, we always have confess’d it.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ho, ho, confess’d it? Hang’d it, have you not?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: No;
You shall not make me welcome.
I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Fie, th’ art a churl. Ye have got a humor there
Does not become a man, ’tis much to blame.
They say, my lords, “Ira furor brevis est,”
But yond man is very angry. Go,
Let him have a table by himself,
For he does neither affect company,
Nor is he fit for’t indeed.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon.
I come to observe, I give thee warning on’t.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I take no heed of thee; th’ art an Athenian, therefore welcome. I myself would have no power; prithee let my meat make thee silent.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I scorn thy meat, ’twould choke me; for I should ne’er flatter thee. O you gods! What a number of men eats Timon, and he sees ’em not! It grieves me to see so many dip their meat in one man’s blood, and all the madness is, he cheers them up too.
I wonder men dare trust themselves with men.
Methinks they should invite them without knives:
Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.

There’s much example for’t: the fellow that sits next him, now parts bread with him, pledges the breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest man to kill him; ’t ’as been prov’d. If I were a huge man, I should fear to drink at meals,
Lest they should spy my windpipe’s dangerous notes:
Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Flow this way? A brave fellow! He keeps his tides well. Those healths will make thee and thy state look ill, Timon.
Here’s that which is too weak to be a sinner,
Honest water, which ne’er left man i’ th’ mire.
This and my food are equals, there’s no odds;
Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.

line.recite: Immortal gods, I crave no pelf,
I pray for no man but myself.
Grant I may never prove so fond,
To trust man on his oath or bond;
Or a harlot for her weeping,
Or a dog that seems a-sleeping,
Or a keeper with my freedom,
Or my friends, if I should need ’em.
Rich men sin, and I eat root.

speech.line: Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Captain Alcibiades, your heart’s in the field now.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a dinner of friends.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: So they were bleeding new, my lord, there’s no meat like ’em; I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Would all those flatterers were thine enemies then, that then thou mightst kill ’em—and bid me to ’em!

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you would once use our hearts, whereby we might express some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves forever perfect.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods themselves have provided that I shall have much help from you: how had you been my friends else? Why have you that charitable title from thousands, did not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told more of you to myself than you can with modesty speak in your own behalf; and thus far I confirm you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any friends, if we should ne’er have need of ’em? They were the most needless creatures living, should we ne’er have use for ’em; and would most resemble sweet instruments hung up in cases, that keeps their sounds to themselves. Why, I have often wish’d myself poorer, that I might come nearer to you. We are born to do benefits; and what better or properer can we call our own than the riches of our friends? O, what a precious comfort ’tis to have so many like brothers commanding one another’s fortunes! O, joy’s e’en made away ere’t can be born! Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks. To forget their faults, I drink to you.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thou weep’st to make them drink, Timon.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Joy had the like conception in our eyes,
And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: I promise you, my lord, you mov’d me much.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Much!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What means that trump?
How now?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Please you, my lord, there are certain ladies most desirous of admittance.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ladies? What are their wills?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which bears that office to signify their pleasures.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I pray let them be admitted.

speech.speaker: CUP.
speech.line: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all
That of his bounties taste! The five best senses
Acknowledge thee their patron, and come freely
To gratulate thy plenteous bosom. There,
Taste, touch, all, pleas’d from thy table rise;
They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: They’re welcome all, let ’em have kind admittance.
Music, make their welcome!

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: You see, my lord, how ample y’ are belov’d.

scene.stagedir: Music. Enter Cupid with the masque of Ladies, as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Hoy-day,
What a sweep of vanity comes this way!
They dance? They are madwomen.
Like madness is the glory of this life,
As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.
We make ourselves fools to disport ourselves,
And spend our flatteries to drink those men
Upon whose age we void it up again
With poisonous spite and envy.
Who lives that’s not depraved or depraves?
Who dies that bears not one spurn to their graves
Of their friends’ gift?
I should fear those that dance before me now
Would one day stamp upon me. ’T ’as been done;
Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

scene.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of Timon, and to show their loves, each single out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hoboys, and cease.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,
Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,
Which was not half so beautiful and kind;
You have added worth unto’t and lustre,
And entertain’d me with mine own device.
I am to thank you for’t.

speech.speaker: 1. LADY. MASK.
speech.line: My lord, you take us even at the best.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Faith, for the worst is filthy, and would not hold taking, I doubt me.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you,
Please you to dispose yourselves.

speech.speaker: ALL LADY. MASK.
speech.line: Most thankfully, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Flavius!

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: The little casket bring me hither.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Yes, my lord.
More jewels yet?
There is no crossing him in ’s humor,
Else I should tell him well (i’ faith, I should),
When all’s spent, he’ld be cross’d then, and he could.
’Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind,
That man might ne’er be wretched for his mind.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Where be our men?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Here, my lord, in readiness.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Our horses!

scene.stagedir: Enter Flavius with the casket. Exit Flaminius.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: O my friends! I have one word
To say to you. Look you, my good lord,
I must entreat you honor me so much
As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,
Kind my lord.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: I am so far already in your gifts—

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: So are we all.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: My lord, there are certain nobles of the Senate
Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: They are fairly welcome.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: I beseech your honor,
Vouchsafe me a word, it does concern you near.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Near? Why then another time I’ll hear thee.
I prithee let’s be provided to show them entertainment.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: I scarce know how.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: May it please your honor, Lord Lucius
(Out of his free love) hath presented to you
Four milk-white horses, trapp’d in silver.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents
Be worthily entertain’d.
How now? What news?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Please you, my lord, that honorable gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company tomorrow to hunt with him, and has sent your honor two brace of greyhounds.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I’ll hunt with him, and let them be receiv’d,
Not without fair reward.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: What will this come to?
He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,
And all out of an empty coffer;
Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,
To show him what a beggar his heart is,
Being of no power to make his wishes good.
His promises fly so beyond his state
That what he speaks is all in debt: he owes
For ev’ry word. He is so kind that he now
Pays interest for’t; his land’s put to their books.
Well, would I were gently put out of office
Before I were forc’d out!
Happier is he that has no friend to feed
Than such that do e’en enemies exceed.
I bleed inwardly for my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You do yourselves
Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits.
Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: O, he’s the very soul of bounty!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: And now I remember, my lord, you gave
Good words the other day of a bay courser
I rode on. ’Tis yours, because you lik’d it.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: O, I beseech you pardon me, my lord, in that.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You may take my word, my lord; I know no man
Can justly praise but what he does affect.
I weigh my friend’s affection with mine own.
I’ll tell you true, I’ll call to you.

speech.speaker: ALL LORDS.
speech.line: O, none so welcome.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I take all and your several visitations
So kind to heart, ’tis not enough to give;
Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,
And ne’er be weary. Alcibiades,
Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich,
It comes in charity to thee; for all thy living
Is ’mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast
Lie in a pitch’d field.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Ay, defil’d land, my lord.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: We are so virtuously bound—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: And so
Am I to you.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: So infinitely endear’d—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: All to you. Lights, more lights!

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: The best of happiness,
Honor, and fortunes keep with you, Lord Timon!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ready for his friends.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Lords and others. Apemantus and Timon remain.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: What a coil’s here!
Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!
I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums
That are given for ’em. Friendship’s full of dregs;
Methinks false hearts should never have sound legs.
Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on curtsies.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen,
I would be good to thee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: No, I’ll nothing; for if I should be brib’d too, there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou giv’st so long, Timon (I fear me), thou wilt give away thyself in paper shortly. What needs these feasts, pomps, and vainglories?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Nay, and you begin to rail on society once, I am sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell, and come with better music.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: So; thou wilt not hear me now, thou shalt not then. I’ll lock thy heaven from thee.
O that men’s ears should be
To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A room in a Senator’s house.
scene.scenedescription: A worried Senator tallies up how much he knows Timon owes, and seeing that Timon is still living extravagantly decides to call in his own debt before Timon is unable to pay. He sends a servant to get the money, telling him not to be put off.
scene.stagedir: Enter a Senator with papers in his hand.

speech.speaker: SEN.
speech.line: And late, five thousand; to Varro and to Isidore
He owes nine thousand, besides my former sum,
Which makes it five and twenty. Still in motion
Of raging waste? It cannot hold, it will not.
If I want gold, steal but a beggar’s dog
And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.
If I would sell my horse and buy twenty more
Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon,
Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me straight
And able horses. No porter at his gate,
But rather one that smiles and still invites
All that pass by. It cannot hold, no reason
Can sound his state in safety. Caphis ho!
Caphis, I say!

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Here, sir, what is your pleasure?

speech.speaker: SEN.
speech.line: Get on your cloak and haste you to Lord Timon;
Importune him for my moneys, be not ceas’d
With slight denial; nor then silenc’d when
“Commend me to your master” and the cap
Plays in the right hand, thus—but tell him
My uses cry to me; I must serve my turn
Out of mine own. His days and times are past,
And my reliances on his fracted dates
Have smit my credit. I love and honor him,
But must not break my back to heal his finger.
Immediate are my needs, and my relief
Must not be toss’d and turn’d to me in words,
But find supply immediate. Get you gone,
Put on a most importunate aspect,
A visage of demand; for I do fear,
When every feather sticks in his own wing,
Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,
Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: I go, sir.

speech.speaker: SEN.
speech.line: Ay, go, sir; take the bonds along with you,
And have the dates in. Come!

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: I will, sir.

speech.speaker: SEN.
speech.line: Go.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A hall in Timon’s house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Steward Flavius, Caphis, Servants of Isidore and Varro, Timon, Alcibiades, Apemantus, Fool, Page, Flaminius, Servilius, Timon’s Servant)
scene.scenedescription: Flavius is distracted by the sheer number of bills being given to him. When Timon comes in from hunting he is importuned by a number of servants handing in their respective masters’ calls for repayment. He cannot understand their pressure. Flavius asks the servants for a bit of time so he can explain matters to Timon, and they agree. They pass the time mocking and being mocked by Apemantus. Timon and Flavius return, the master upbraiding Flavius for not telling him earlier just how poor he actually is and Flavius pointing out that he tried but Timon would never listen. Timon orders Flavius to sell all of Timon’s land, but it has all been mortgaged already. Flavius lectures him until Timon finally stops him. He reassures himself with the thought that at least he spent out of generosity. He sends servants to ask some of his friends to help him out. Flavius tells him he has tried this already, but Timon is certain they will not desert him.
scene.stagedir: Enter Steward Flavius with many bills in his hand.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: No care, no stop, so senseless of expense,
That he will neither know how to maintain it,
Nor cease his flow of riot. Takes no accompt
How things go from him, nor resumes no care
Of what is to continue. Never mind
Was to be so unwise, to be so kind.
What shall be done, he will not hear, till feel.
I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.
Fie, fie, fie, fie!

scene.stagedir: Enter Caphis and the Servants of Isidore and Varro.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Good even, Varro. What,
You come for money?

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: Is’t not your business too?

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: It is; and yours too, Isidore?

speech.speaker: ISID. SERV.
speech.line: It is so.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Would we were all discharg’d!

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: I fear it.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Here comes the lord.

scene.stagedir: Enter Timon and his Train with Alcibiades.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: So soon as dinner’s done, we’ll forth again,
My Alcibiades.—With me, what is your will?

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Dues? Whence are you?

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Of Athens here, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Go to my steward.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off
To the succession of new days this month.
My master is awak’d by great occasion
To call upon his own, and humbly prays you
That with your other noble parts You’ll suit
In giving him his right.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Mine honest friend,
I prithee but repair to me next morning.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Nay, good my lord—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Contain thyself, good friend.

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: One Varro’s servant, my good lord—

speech.speaker: ISID. SERV.
speech.line: From Isidore;
He humbly prays your speedy payment.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: If you did know, my lord, my master’s wants—

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: ’Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks
And past.

speech.speaker: ISID. SERV.
speech.line: Your steward puts me off, my lord,
And I am sent expressly to your lordship.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Give me breath.
I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on,
I’ll wait upon you instantly.
Come hither. Pray you,
How goes the world, that I am thus encount’red
With clamorous demands of debt, broken bonds,
And the detention of long since due debts,
Against my honor?

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Please you, gentlemen,
The time is unagreeable to this business.
Your importunacy cease till after dinner,
That I may make his lordship understand
Wherefore you are not paid.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain’d.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Pray draw near.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Stay, stay, here comes the Fool with
Apemantus, let’s ha’ some sport with ’em.

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: Hang him, he’ll abuse us.

speech.speaker: ISID. SERV.
speech.line: A plague upon him, dog!

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: How dost, Fool?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: I speak not to thee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: No, ’tis to thyself.
Come away.

speech.speaker: ISID. SERV.
speech.line: There’s the Fool hangs on your back already.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: No, thou stand’st single, th’ art not on him yet.

speech.speaker: CAPH.
speech.line: Where’s the Fool now?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: He last ask’d the question. Poor rogues, and usurers’ men, bawds between gold and want!

speech.speaker: ALL SERV.
speech.line: What are we, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Asses.

speech.speaker: ALL SERV.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: That you ask me what you are, and do not know yourselves. Speak to ’em, Fool.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: How do you, gentlemen?

speech.speaker: ALL SERV.
speech.line: Gramercies, good Fool; how does your mistress?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: She’s e’en setting on water to scald such chickens as you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Good, gramercy.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Look you, here comes my master’s page.

speech.speaker: TIM. PAGE.
speech.line: Why, how now, captain? What do you in this wise company? How dost thou, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answer thee profitably.

speech.speaker: TIM. PAGE.
speech.line: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of these letters, I know not which is which.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Canst not read?

speech.speaker: TIM. PAGE.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: There will little learning die then that day thou art hang’d. This is to Lord Timon, this to Alcibiades. Go, thou wast born a bastard, and thou’t die a bawd.

speech.speaker: TIM. PAGE.
speech.line: Thou wast whelp’d a dog, and thou shalt famish a dog’s death. Answer not, I am gone.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: E’en so thou outrun’st grace. Fool, I will go with you to Lord Timon’s.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Will you leave me there?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: If Timon stay at home. You three serve three usurers?

speech.speaker: ALL SERV.
speech.line: Ay, would they serv’d us!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: So would I—as good a trick as ever hangman serv’d thief.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Are you three usurers’ men?

speech.speaker: ALL SERV.
speech.line: Ay, Fool.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant; my mistress is one, and I am her fool. When men come to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly, and go away merry; but they enter my master’s house merrily, and go away sadly. The reason of this?

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: I could render one.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster and a knave, which notwithstanding, thou shalt be no less esteem’d.

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: What is a whoremaster, Fool?

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee. ’Tis a spirit; sometime’t appears like a lord, sometime like a lawyer, sometime like a philosopher, with two stones more than ’s artificial one. He is very often like a knight; and, generally, in all shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to thirteen, this spirit walks in.

speech.speaker: VAR. SERV.
speech.line: Thou art not altogether a fool.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: Nor thou altogether a wise man; as much foolery as I have, so much wit thou lack’st.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: That answer might have become Apemantus.

speech.speaker: ALL SERV.
speech.line: Aside, aside, here comes Lord Timon.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Come with me, Fool, come.

speech.speaker: FOOL.
speech.line: I do not always follow lover, elder brother, and woman; sometime the philosopher.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Pray you walk near, I’ll speak with you anon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You make me marvel wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laid my state before me,
That I might so have rated my expense
As I had leave of means.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: You would not hear me;
At many leisures I propos’d.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Go to!
Perchance some single vantages you took,
When my indisposition put you back,
And that unaptness made your minister
Thus to excuse yourself.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: O my good lord,
At many times I brought in my accompts,
Laid them before you; you would throw them off,
And say you found them in mine honesty.
When for some trifling present you have bid me
Return so much, I have shook my head, and wept;
Yea, ’gainst th’ authority of manners, pray’d you
To hold your hand more close. I did endure
Not seldom, nor no slight checks, when I have
Prompted you in the ebb of your estate
And your great flow of debts. My lov’d lord,
Though you hear now (too late), yet now’s a time:
The greatest of your having lacks a half
To pay your present debts.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Let all my land be sold.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: ’Tis all engag’d, some forfeited and gone,
And what remains will hardly stop the mouth
Of present dues. The future comes apace;
What shall defend the interim? And at length
How goes our reck’ning?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: O my good lord, the world is but a word;
Were it all yours to give it in a breath,
How quickly were it gone!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You tell me true.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood,
Call me before th’ exactest auditors,
And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me,
When all our offices have been oppress’d
With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept
With drunken spilth of wine, when every room
Hath blaz’d with lights and bray’d with minstrelsy,
I have retir’d me to a wasteful cock,
And set mine eyes at flow.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Prithee no more.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!
How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants
This night englutted! Who is not Timon’s?
What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon’s?
Great Timon! Noble, worthy, royal Timon!
Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,
The breath is gone whereof this praise is made.
Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter show’rs,
These flies are couch’d.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Come, sermon me no further.
No villainous bounty yet hath pass’d my heart;
Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack
To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart;
If I would broach the vessels of my love,
And try the argument of hearts, by borrowing,
Men and men’s fortunes could I frankly use
As I can bid thee speak.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Assurance bless your thoughts!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: And in some sort these wants of mine are crown’d,
That I account them blessings; for by these
Shall I try friends. You shall perceive how you
Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.
Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

scene.stagedir: Enter three servants: Flaminius, Servilius, and Timon’s Servant.

speech.speaker: THREE SERVANTS.
speech.line: My lord? My lord?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I will dispatch you severally: to Servilius you to Lord Lucius; to Flaminius to Lord Lucullus you—I hunted with his honor today; to the other you to Sempronius. Commend me to their loves; and I am proud, say, that my occasions have found time to use ’em toward a supply of money. Let the request be fifty talents.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: As you have said, my lord.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Go you, sir, to the senators—
Of whom, even to the state’s best health, I have
Deserv’d this hearing—bid ’em send o’ th’ instant
A thousand talents to me.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: I have been bold
(For that I knew it the most general way)
To them to use your signet and your name,
But they do shake their heads, and I am here
No richer in return.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Is’t true? Can ’t be?

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice,
That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot
Do what they would, are sorry; you are honorable,
But yet they could have wish’d—they know not—
Something hath been amiss—a noble nature
May catch a wrench—would all were well—’tis pity—
And so, intending other serious matters,
After distasteful looks, and these hard fractions,
With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods,
They froze me into silence.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You gods, reward them!
Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows
Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:
Their blood is cak’d, ’tis cold, it seldom flows;
’Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
And nature, as it grows again toward earth,
Is fashion’d for the journey, dull and heavy.
Go to Ventidius. (Prithee be not sad,
Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak,
No blame belongs to thee.) Ventidius lately
Buried his father, by whose death he’s stepp’d
Into a great estate. When he was poor,
Imprison’d, and in scarcity of friends,
I clear’d him with five talents. Greet him from me,
Bid him suppose some good necessity
Touches his friend, which craves to be rememb’red
With those five talents. That had, give’t these fellows
To whom ’tis instant due. Nev’r speak or think
That Timon’s fortunes ’mong his friends can sink.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: I would I could not think it! That thought is bounty’s foe;
Being free itself, it thinks all others so.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A room in Lucullus’ house.
scene.scenedescription: Lucullus is disappointed when Timon’s servant Flaminius comes to him not with a gift but with a request for a loan. He berates Timon for his prodigality and states that it is no time to lend money just for friendship. He tries to bribe Flaminius into denying that they saw each other. Flaminius is disgusted.
scene.stagedir: Flaminius waiting to speak with a lord Lucullus from his master, enters Lucullus’s Servant to him.

speech.speaker: LUCUL. SERV.
speech.line: I have told my lord of you, he is coming down to you.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: I thank you, sir.

speech.speaker: LUCUL. SERV.
speech.line: Here’s my lord.

speech.speaker: LUCUL.
speech.line: One of Lord Timon’s men? A gift, I warrant. Why, this hits right; I dreamt of a silver basin and ew’r tonight.—Flaminius, honest Flaminius, you are very respectively welcome, sir. Fill me some wine.
And how does that honorable, complete, free-hearted gentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lord and master?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: His health is well, sir.

speech.speaker: LUCUL.
speech.line: I am right glad that his health is well, sir; and what hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty Flaminius?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir, which, in my lord’s behalf, I come to entreat your honor to supply; who, having great and instant occasion to use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship to furnish him, nothing doubting your present assistance therein.

speech.speaker: LUCUL.
speech.line: La, la, la, la! “nothing doubting,” says he? Alas, good lord! A noble gentleman ’tis, if he would not keep so good a house. Many a time and often I ha’ din’d with him, and told him on’t, and come again to supper to him of purpose to have him spend less, and yet he would embrace no counsel, take no warning by my coming. Every man has his fault, and honesty is his. I ha’ told him on’t, but I could ne’er get him from’t.

speech.speaker: LUCUL. SERV.
speech.line: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

speech.speaker: LUCUL.
speech.line: Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise. Here’s to thee.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.

speech.speaker: LUCUL.
speech.line: I have observ’d thee always for a towardly prompt spirit—give thee thy due—and one that knows what belongs to reason; and canst use the time well, if the time use thee well. Good parts in thee!
Get you gone, sirrah.

Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord’s a bountiful gentleman, but thou art wise, and thou know’st well enough (although thou com’st to me) that this is no time to lend money, especially upon bare friendship without security. Here’s three solidares for thee; good boy, wink at me, and say thou saw’st me not. Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Is’t possible the world should so much differ,
And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness,
To him that worships thee!

speech.speaker: LUCUL.
speech.line: Ha? Now I see thou art a fool, and fit for thy master.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: May these add to the number that may scald thee!
Let molten coin be thy damnation,
Thou disease of a friend, and not himself!
Has friendship such a faint and milky heart,
It turns in less than two nights? O you gods!
I feel my master’s passion. This slave
Unto his honor has my lord’s meat in him;
Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment
When he is turn’d to poison?
O, may diseases only work upon’t!
And when he’s sick to death, let not that part of nature
Which my lord paid for, be of any power
To expel sickness, but prolong his hour!

scene.scenedescription: Three strangers tell Lucius that Timon is broke, but Lucius finds it hard to believe. He professes outrage that Lucullus refused to help him. Immediately after Lucius says that he would never refuse to help Timon out, Timon’s servant Servilius approaches and asks him for a loan. Lucius pretends that he has no money available and therefore can’t help. The strangers comment on Lucius’s hypocrisy and ingratitude.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Who, the Lord Timon? He is my very good friend, and an honorable gentleman.

speech.speaker: 1. STRAN.
speech.line: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers to him. But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and which I hear from common rumors, now Lord Timon’s happy hours are done and past, and his estate shrinks from him.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.

speech.speaker: 2. STRAN.
speech.line: But believe you this, my lord, that not long ago one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow so many talents, nay, urg’d extremely for’t, and show’d what necessity belong’d to’t, and yet was denied.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: 2. STRAN.
speech.line: I tell you, denied, my lord.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: What a strange case was that! Now before the gods, I am asham’d on’t. Denied that honorable man? There was very little honor show’d in’t. For my own part, I must needs confess, I have receiv’d some small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels, and such like trifles—nothing comparing to his—yet had he mistook him and sent to me, I should ne’er have denied his occasion so many talents.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: See, by good hap, yonder’s my lord; I have sweat to see his honor. My honor’d lord—

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Servilius? You are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well, commend me to thy honorable virtuous lord, my very exquisite friend.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: May it please your honor, my lord hath sent—

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Ha? What has he sent? I am so much endear’d to that lord: he’s ever sending. How shall I thank him, think’st thou? And what has he sent now?

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: H’as only sent his present occasion now, my lord; requesting your lordship to supply his instant use with so many talents.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I know his lordship is but merry with me;
He cannot want fifty—five hundred talents.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.
If his occasion were not virtuous,
I should not urge it half so faithfully.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: Upon my soul, ’tis true, sir.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself against such a good time, when I might ha’ shown myself honorable! How unluckily it happ’ned that I should purchase the day before for a little part, and undo a great deal of honor! Servilius, now before the gods, I am not able to do (the more beast, I say!)—I was sending to use Lord Timon myself, these gentlemen can witness; but I would not, for the wealth of Athens, I had done’t now. Commend me bountifully to his good lordship, and I hope his honor will conceive the fairest of me, because I have no power to be kind. And tell him this from me, I count it one of my greatest afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an honorable gentleman. Good Servilius, will you befriend me so far as to use mine own words to him?

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: Yes, sir, I shall.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I’ll look you out a good turn, Servilius.—
True, as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed,
And he that’s once denied will hardly speed.

speech.speaker: 1. STRAN.
speech.line: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

speech.speaker: 2. STRAN.
speech.line: Ay, too well.

speech.speaker: 1. STRAN.
speech.line: Why, this is the world’s soul, and just of the same piece
Is every flatterer’s sport. Who can call him
His friend that dips in the same dish? For, in
My knowing, Timon has been this lord’s father,
And kept his credit with his purse;
Supported his estate, nay, Timon’s money
Has paid his men their wages. He ne’er drinks
But Timon’s silver treads upon his lip,
And yet—O, see the monstrousness of man
When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!—
He does deny him (in respect of his)
What charitable men afford to beggars.

speech.speaker: 3. STRAN.
speech.line: Religion groans at it.

speech.speaker: 1. STRAN.
speech.line: For mine own part,
I never tasted Timon in my life,
Nor came any of his bounties over me
To mark me for his friend; yet, I protest,
For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue,
And honorable carriage,
Had his necessity made use of me,
I would have put my wealth into donation,
And the best half should have return’d to him,
So much I love his heart. But I perceive
Men must learn now with pity to dispense,
For policy sits above conscience.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A room in Sempronius’s house.
scene.scenedescription: One of Timon’s servants asks Sempronius to help Timon out, but Sempronius feels insulted that he was asked last, and, taking this as a slight, refuses to help as a point of honor. The servant comments on his hypocrisy, but realizes that Timon is out of people to ask for aid.
scene.stagedir: Enter Timon’s Servant with Sempronius, another of Timon’s friends.

speech.speaker: SEM.
speech.line: Must he needs trouble me in’t—hum!—’bove all others?
He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;
And now Ventidius is wealthy too,
Whom he redeem’d from prison. All these
Owes their estates unto him.

speech.speaker: TIM. SERV.
speech.line: My lord,
They have all been touch’d and found base metal,
For they have all denied him.

speech.speaker: SEM.
speech.line: How? Have they denied him?
Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him,
And does he send to me? Three? Humh!
It shows but little love or judgment in him.
Must I be his last refuge? His friends, like physicians,
Thrive, give him over; must I take th’ cure upon me?
H’as much disgrac’d me in’t, I’m angry at him,
That might have known my place. I see no sense for’t,
But his occasions might have wooed me first;
For, in my conscience, I was the first man
That e’er received gift from him;
And does he think so backwardly of me now,
That I’ll requite it last? No!
So it may prove an argument of laughter
To th’ rest, and ’mongst lords I be thought a fool.
I’d rather than the worth of thrice the sum
H’ad sent to me first, but for my mind’s sake;
I’d such a courage to do him good. But now return,
And with their faint reply this answer join:
Who bates mine honor shall not know my coin.

speech.speaker: TIM. SERV.
speech.line: Excellent! Your lordship’s a goodly villain. The devil knew not what he did when he made man politic; he cross’d himself by’t; and I cannot think but, in the end, the villainies of man will set him clear. How fairly this lord strives to appear foul! Takes virtuous copies to be wicked; like those that under hot ardent zeal would set whole realms on fire; of such a nature is his politic love.
This was my lord’s best hope, now all are fled,
Save only the gods. Now his friends are dead,
Doors, that were ne’er acquainted with their wards
Many a bounteous year, must be employ’d
Now to guard sure their master.
