And this is all a liberal course allows:
Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A hall in Timon’s house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Varro’s two Servants, Titus, Servants of Timon’s creditors, Lucius’ Servant, Hortensius, Philotus, Flaminius, Steward Flavius, Servilius, Timon)
scene.scenedescription: All of Timon’s creditors’ servants throng the hall of Timon’s house, waiting for him. Flavius tries to sneak out but is recognized, and tells them bluntly that there’s no money for them here. They refuse to believe Servilius when he claims that Timon is sick, as they think this is just a trick to avoid them. Timon comes out in a rage and they press on him, and it becomes clear to them that they will not be receiving anything. They leave. Timon sends Flavius to invite all of his so-called friends to another feast. Flavius protests that there’s no money for one, but Timon tells him that he’ll manage.
scene.stagedir: Enter Varro’s two Servants, meeting Titus and others, all servants of Timon’s creditors, to wait for his coming out. Then enter Lucius’ Servant and Hortensius.

speech.speaker: 1. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: Well met, good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: The like to you, kind Varro.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Lucius!
What, do we meet together?

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Ay, and I think
One business does command us all; for mine
Is money.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: So is theirs and ours.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: And, sir, Philotus too!

speech.speaker: PHI.
speech.line: Good day at once.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Welcome, good brother.
What do you think the hour?

speech.speaker: PHI.
speech.line: Laboring for nine.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: So much?

speech.speaker: PHI.
speech.line: Is not my lord seen yet?

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Not yet.

speech.speaker: PHI.
speech.line: I wonder on’t, he was wont to shine at seven.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Ay, but the days are wax’d shorter with him.
You must consider that a prodigal course
Is like the sun’s, but not like his recoverable,
I fear. ’Tis deepest winter in Lord Timon’s purse;
That is, one may reach deep enough and yet
Find little.

speech.speaker: PHI.
speech.line: I am of your fear for that.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: I’ll show you how t’ observe a strange event.
Your lord sends now for money.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Most true, he does.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: And he wears jewels now of Timon’s gift,
For which I wait for money.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: It is against my heart.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Mark how strange it shows,
Timon in this should pay more than he owes;
And e’en as if your lord should wear rich jewels
And send for money for ’em.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: I’m weary of this charge, the gods can witness.
I know my lord hath spent of Timon’s wealth,
And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

speech.speaker: 1. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: Yes, mine’s three thousand crowns; what’s yours?

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Five thousand mine.

speech.speaker: 1. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: ’Tis much deep, and it should seem by th’ sum
Your master’s confidence was above mine,
Else surely his had equall’d.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: One of Lord Timon’s men.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Flaminius? Sir, a word. Pray is my lord ready to come forth?

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: No, indeed he is not.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: We attend his lordship; pray signify so much.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: I need not tell him that, he knows you are too diligent.

scene.stagedir: Enter Steward Flavius in a cloak, muffled.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Ha! Is not that his steward muffled so?
He goes away in a cloud; call him, call him.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: Do you hear, sir?

speech.speaker: 2. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: By your leave, sir—

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: What do ye ask of me, my friend?

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: We wait for certain money here, sir.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Ay,
If money were as certain as your waiting,
’Twere sure enough.
Why then preferr’d you not your sums and bills
When your false masters eat of my lord’s meat?
Then they could smile, and fawn upon his debts,
And take down th’ int’rest into their glutt’nous maws.
You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up,
Let me pass quietly.
Believe’t, my lord and I have made an end:
I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Ay, but this answer will not serve.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: If ’twill not serve, ’tis not so base as you,
For you serve knaves.

speech.speaker: 1. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: How? What does his cashier’d worship mutter?

speech.speaker: 2. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: No matter what, he’s poor, and that’s revenge enough. Who can speak broader than he that has no house to put his head in? Such may rail against great buildings.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: O, here’s Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some other hour, I should derive much from’t; for take’t of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to discontent. His comfortable temper has forsook him, he’s much out of health, and keeps his chamber.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Many do keep their chambers are not sick;
And if it be so far beyond his health,
Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts,
And make a clear way to the gods.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: Good gods!

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Servilius, help! My lord, my lord!

scene.stagedir: Enter Timon in a rage, Flaminius following.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What, are my doors oppos’d against my passage?
Have I been ever free, and must my house
Be my retentive enemy? My jail?
The place which I have feasted, does it now
(Like all mankind) show me an iron heart?

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Put in now, Titus.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: My lord, here is my bill.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Here’s mine.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: And mine, my lord.

speech.speaker: BOTH 1. VAR. SERV. AND 2. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: And ours, my lord.

speech.speaker: PHI.
speech.line: All our bills.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Knock me down with ’em, cleave me to the girdle!

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Alas, my lord—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Cut my heart in sums.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: Mine, fifty talents.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Tell out my blood.

speech.speaker: LUC. SERV.
speech.line: Five thousand crowns, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Five thousand drops pays that. What yours? And yours?

speech.speaker: 1. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: My lord—

speech.speaker: 2. VAR. SERV.
speech.line: My lord—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their caps at their money. These debts may well be call’d desperate ones, for a madman owes ’em.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: They have e’en put my breath from me, the slaves.
Creditors? Devils!

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: My dear lord—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What if it should be so?

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: My lord—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I’ll have it so. My steward!

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Here, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again,
Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius—all.
I’ll once more feast the rascals.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: O my lord,
You only speak from your distracted soul;
There’s not so much left to furnish out
A moderate table.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Be it not in thy care;
Go, I charge thee, invite them all, let in the tide
Of knaves once more; my cook and I’ll provide.

scene.scenedescription: Alcibiades pleads before the Senate for the life of one of his soldiers who has been condemned to death, arguing that his crime was committed in the heat of the moment and that sending him back to war would allow him to redeem himself. The Senators refuse all his pleading, and when he continues and goes too far, they exile him. Furious, he plans to take his soldiers and wage war against Athens on his own account.
scene.stagedir: Enter three Senators at one door, Alcibiades meeting them, with Attendants.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: My lord, you have my voice to’t; the fault’s
Bloody; ’tis necessary he should die.
Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: Most true; the law shall bruise ’em.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Honor, health, and compassion to the Senate!

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Now, captain?

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I am an humble suitor to your virtues;
For pity is the virtue of the law,
And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy
Upon a friend of mine, who in hot blood
Hath stepp’d into the law, which is past depth
To those that (without heed) do plunge into’t.
He is a man (setting his fate aside)
Of comely virtues;
Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice
(An honor in him which buys out his fault),
But with a noble fury and fair spirit,
Seeing his reputation touch’d to death,
He did oppose his foe;
And with such sober and unnoted passion
He did behoove his anger, ere ’twas spent,
As if he had but prov’d an argument.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: You undergo too strict a paradox,
Striving to make an ugly deed look fair.
Your words have took such pains as if they labor’d
To bring manslaughter into form, and set quarrelling
Upon the head of valor; which indeed
Is valor misbegot, and came into the world
When sects and factions were newly born.
He’s truly valiant that can wisely suffer
The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs
His outsides, to wear them like his raiment, carelessly,
And ne’er prefer his injuries to his heart,
To bring it into danger.
If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill,
What folly ’tis to hazard life for ill!

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: My lord—

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: You cannot make gross sins look clear;
To revenge is no valor, but to bear.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: My lords, then, under favor, pardon me
If I speak like a captain.
Why do fond men expose themselves to battle,
And not endure all threats? Sleep upon’t,
And let the foes quietly cut their throats
Without repugnancy? If there be
Such valor in the bearing, what make we
Abroad? Why then, women are more valiant
That stay at home, if bearing carry it;
And the ass more captain than the lion, the fellow
Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,
If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords,
As you are great, be pitifully good.
Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?
To kill, I grant, is sin’s extremest gust,
But in defense, by mercy, ’tis most just.
To be in anger is impiety;
But who is man that is not angry?
Weigh but the crime with this.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: You breathe in vain.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: In vain? His service done
At Lacedaemon and Byzantium
Were a sufficient briber for his life.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Why, I say, my lords, h’as done fair service,
And slain in fight many of your enemies.
How full of valor did he bear himself
In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: He has made too much plenty with ’em.
He’s a sworn rioter; he has a sin that often
Drowns him and takes his valor prisoner.
If there were no foes, that were enough
To overcome him. In that beastly fury
He has been known to commit outrages
And cherish factions. ’Tis inferr’d to us,
His days are foul and his drink dangerous.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: He dies.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Hard fate! He might have died in war.
My lords, if not for any parts in him—
Though his right arm might purchase his own time
And be in debt to none—yet more to move you,
Take my deserts to his, and join ’em both;
And for I know your reverend ages love
Security, I’ll pawn my victories, all
My honor to you, upon his good returns.
If by this crime he owes the law his life,
Why, let the war receive’t in valiant gore,
For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: We are for law, he dies, urge it no more
On height of our displeasure. Friend, or brother,
He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Must it be so? It must not be. My lords,
I do beseech you know me.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Call me to your remembrances.

speech.speaker: 3. SEN.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I cannot think but your age has forgot me,
It could not else be I should prove so base
To sue and be denied such common grace.
My wounds ache at you.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Do you dare our anger?
’Tis in few words, but spacious in effect:
We banish thee forever.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Banish me?
Banish your dotage, banish usury,
That makes the Senate ugly!

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: If after two days’ shine Athens contain thee,
Attend our weightier judgment. And not to swell our spirit,
He shall be executed presently.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Now the gods keep you old enough that you may live
Only in bone, that none may look on you!
I’m worse than mad. I have kept back their foes,
While they have told their money, and let out
Their coin upon large interest—I myself
Rich only in large hurts. All those, for this?
Is this the balsom that the usuring Senate
Pours into captains’ wounds? Banishment!
It comes not ill; I hate not to be banish’d,
It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury,
That I may strike at Athens. I’ll cheer up
My discontented troops, and lay for hearts.
’Tis honor with most lands to be at odds;
Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A banqueting-room in Timon’s house.
scene.scenedescription: Timon’s false friends arrive at Timon’s, convincing themselves that Timon’s requests for help the other day were only to test them. They apologize to Timon for not sending him any money, all explaining that they had no ready money on them at the time. Timon tells them to think nothing of it and seats them. He speaks a grace, and then uncovers the dishes, which have nothing in them but warm water and stones. He throws the water at them while cursing at them and driving them out of his house. Once he has gone, they sneak back in to pick up their belongings, including, in one case, an expensive jewel that Timon gave to him the other day. They assure each other that Timon is clearly mad.
scene.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending.
Enter divers friends of Timon, Senators and other Lords, at several doors.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: The good time of day to you, sir.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: I also wish it to you. I think this honorable lord did but try us this other day.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Upon that were my thoughts tiring when we encount’red. I hope it is not so low with him as he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: I should think so. He hath sent me an earnest inviting, which many my near occasions did urge me to put off; but he hath conjur’d me beyond them, and I must needs appear.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate business, but he would not hear my excuse. I am sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my provision was out.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how all things go.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Every man here’s so. What would he have borrow’d of you?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: A thousand pieces.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: A thousand pieces?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: What of you?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: He sent to me, sir—Here he comes.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: The swallow follows not summer more willing than we your lordship.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Nor more willingly leaves winter, such summer birds are men.—Gentlemen, our dinner will not recompense this long stay; feast your ears with the music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o’ th’ trumpet’s sound; we shall to’t presently.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordship that I return’d you an empty messenger.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: My noble lord—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: My most honorable lord, I am e’en sick of shame that, when your lordship this other day sent to me, I was so unfortunate a beggar.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Think not on’t, sir.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: If you had sent but two hours before—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.—Come, bring in all together!

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: All cover’d dishes!

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yield it.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: How do you? What’s the news?

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: Alcibiades is banish’d: hear you of it?

speech.speaker: BOTH 1. LORD. AND 2. LORD.
speech.line: Alcibiades banish’d?

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: ’Tis so, be sure of it.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: How? How?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: I pray you, upon what?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: I’ll tell you more anon. Here’s a noble feast toward.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: This is the old man still.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: Will’t hold? Will’t hold?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: It does; but time will—and so—

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: I do conceive.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would to the lip of his mistress; your diet shall be in all places alike. Make not a city feast of it, to let the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place; sit, sit. The gods require our thanks.

You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with thankfulness. For your own gifts, make yourselves prais’d; but reserve still to give, lest your deities be despis’d. Lend to each man enough, that one need not lend to another; for were your godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the gods. Make the meat be belov’d more than the man that gives it. Let no assembly of twenty be without a score of villains. If there sit twelve women at the table, let a dozen of them be—as they are. The rest of your fees, O gods—the senators of Athens, together with the common lag of people—what is amiss in them, you gods, make suitable for destruction. For these my present friends, as they are to me nothing, so in nothing bless them, and to nothing are they welcome.
Uncover, dogs, and lap!

scene.stagedir: The dishes are uncovered and seen to be full of warm water.

speech.speaker: SOME SPEAK.
speech.line: What does his lordship mean?

speech.speaker: SOME OTHER.
speech.line: I know not.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: May you a better feast never behold,
You knot of mouth-friends! Smoke and lukewarm water
Is your perfection. This is Timon’s last,
Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,
Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces
Your reeking villainy.
speech.stagedir: Throwing the water in their faces.
speech.line: Live loath’d, and long,
Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites,
Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears,
You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time’s flies,
Cap-and-knee slaves, vapors, and minute-jacks!
Of man and beast the infinite malady
Crust you quite o’er! What, dost thou go?
Soft, take thy physic first—thou too—and thou;
Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none.
speech.stagedir: Throws the dishes at them, and drives them out.
speech.line: What? All in motion? Henceforth be no feast
Whereat a villain’s not a welcome guest.
Burn house! Sink Athens! Henceforth hated be
Of Timon man and all humanity!

scene.stagedir: Enter the Senators with other Lords again.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: How now, my lords?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Know you the quality of Lord Timon’s fury?

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: Push, did you see my cap?

speech.speaker: 4. LORD.
speech.line: I have lost my gown.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: He’s but a mad lord, and nought but humors sways him. He gave me a jewel th’ other day, and now he has beat it out of my hat. Did you see my jewel?

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: Did you see my cap?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Here ’tis,

speech.speaker: 4. LORD.
speech.line: Here lies my gown.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD.
speech.line: Let’s make no stay.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD.
speech.line: Lord Timon’s mad.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD.
speech.line: I feel’t upon my bones.

speech.speaker: 4. LORD.
speech.line: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt the Senators and other Lords.

scene.scenedescription: Timon has left Athens, and as he walks out of it he takes the time to curse its walls and all within it, wishing that anarchy will descend on it, with all good things lost and only evil holding sway.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall
That girdles in those wolves, dive in the earth,
And fence not Athens! Matrons, turn incontinent!
Obedience, fail in children! Slaves and fools,
Pluck the grave wrinkled Senate from the bench,
And minister in their steads! To general filths
Convert o’ th’ instant, green virginity!
Do’t in your parents’ eyes! Bankrupts, hold fast;
Rather than render back, out with your knives,
And cut your trusters’ throats! Bound servants, steal;
Large-handed robbers your grave masters are,
And pill by law. Maid, to thy master’s bed,
Thy mistress is o’ th’ brothel! Son of sixteen,
Pluck the lin’d crutch from thy old limping sire,
With it beat out his brains! Piety, and fear,
Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth,
Domestic awe, night-rest, and neighborhood,
Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades,
Degrees, observances, customs, and laws,
Decline to your confounding contraries;
And yet confusion live! Plagues incident to men,
Your potent and infectious fevers heap
On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica,
Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt
As lamely as their manners! Lust, and liberty,
Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth,
That ’gainst the stream of virtue they may strive,
And drown themselves in riot! Itches, blains,
Sow all th’ Athenian bosoms, and their crop
Be general leprosy! Breath, infect breath,
That their society (as their friendship) may
Be merely poison! Nothing I’ll bear from thee
But nakedness, thou detestable town!
Take thou that too, with multiplying bans!
Timon will to the woods, where he shall find
Th’ unkindest beast more kinder than mankind.
The gods confound (hear me, you good gods all)
Th’ Athenians both within and out that wall!
And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow
To the whole race of mankind, high and low!
Amen.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A room in Timon’s house.
scene.scenedescription: Timon’s former servants bid farewell to one another, remembering what a good master he was. Flavius divides up his money between them, and they all agree to remain friends. Flavius resolves to find Timon and serve him for as long as he can.
scene.stagedir: Enter Steward Flavius with two of Timon’s Servants, Flaminius and Servilius.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Hear you, Master Steward, where’s our master?
Are we undone, cast off, nothing remaining?

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Alack, my fellows, what should I say to you?
Let me be recorded by the righteous gods,
I am as poor as you.

speech.speaker: FLAM.
speech.line: Such a house broke?
So noble a master fall’n, all gone, and not
One friend to take his fortune by the arm,
And go along with him.

speech.speaker: SER.
speech.line: As we do turn our backs
From our companion thrown into his grave,
So his familiars to his buried fortunes
Slink all away, leave their false vows with him,
Like empty purses pick’d; and his poor self,
A dedicated beggar to the air,
With his disease of all-shunn’d poverty,
Walks, like contempt, alone. More of our fellows.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: All broken implements of a ruin’d house.

speech.speaker: TIM. SERV.
speech.line: Yet do our hearts wear Timon’s livery,
That see I by our faces; we are fellows still,
Serving alike in sorrow. Leak’d is our bark,
And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck,
Hearing the surges threat; we must all part
Into this sea of air.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Good fellows all,
The latest of my wealth I’ll share amongst you.
Where ever we shall meet, for Timon’s sake
Let’s yet be fellows. Let’s shake our heads, and say,
As ’twere a knell unto our master’s fortunes,
“We have seen better days.” Let each take some;
Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more:
Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor.
O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!
Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,
Since riches point to misery and contempt?
Who would be so mock’d with glory, or to live
But in a dream of friendship,
To have his pomp, and all what state compounds,
But only painted, like his varnish’d friends?
Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,
Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood,
When man’s worst sin is, he does too much good!
Who then dares to be half so kind again?
For bounty, that makes gods, do still mar men.
My dearest lord, blest to be most accurs’d,
Rich only to be wretched, thy great fortunes
Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord,
He’s flung in rage from this ingrateful seat
Of monstrous friends; nor has he with him to
Supply his life, or that which can command it.
I’ll follow and inquire him out.
I’ll ever serve his mind with my best will;
Whilst I have gold, I’ll be his steward still.

scene.scenelocation: Woods and cave near the seashore.
scene.scenepersonae: (Timon, Alcibiades, Phrynia and Timandra, Apemantus, Bandits, Steward Flavius)
scene.scenedescription: Timon is living in a cave in the woods; he curses the world as he digs to find roots to eat. Instead, he comes across a bag of gold. He hides it again as Alcibiades, his two mistresses and his army march in. Alcibiades does not at first recognize Timon, whose ruin he has not heard of. He tries to do Timon some good, but the misanthrope merely snarls at him and insults him. Timon refuses to take Alcibiades’s gold, though he wishes him luck in his war against Athens, though hoping that once Alcibiades has vanquished he’ll be destroyed as well. Timon offers Alcibiades some of the gold he found to pay the soldiers. The two women crawlingly ask him for gold, and he gives it to them while calling them whores and telling them to infect all humanity with their diseases. Alcibiades and his company leave, to Timon’s relief. He continues digging for food, and finds a root just as Apemantus arrives, looking for him. Aemantus accuses Timon of being a poseur and of aping him, and counsels him to become a flatterer instead. They rival each other in their loathing of mankind, and hatred of one another. Apemantus finally leaves, but to revenge himself announces that he’ll tell everyone that Timon has gold, so that he’ll never be left alone. A group of thieves soon arrive to steal Timon’s gold, but he gives them a sermon on why thieving is good and encourages them to engage in wholesale looting. They are so disturbed by his rant that they decide to become honest men, and leave. Flavius arrives, having finally found Timon. He is distressed at Timon’s pitiable state and insists that he still wants to serve his former master. Timon admits that there may be such a thing as an honest man, and excepts him from his misanthropic view of humanity, but still offers him gold on the condition that he will live away from the rest of mankind. Flavius asks to be allowed to stay with Timon, but Timon refuses.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth
Rotten humidity; below thy sister’s orb
Infect the air! Twinn’d brothers of one womb,
Whose procreation, residence, and birth
Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes,
The greater scorns the lesser. Not nature
(To whom all sores lay siege) can bear great fortune
But by contempt of nature.
Raise me this beggar, and deny’t that lord,
The senator shall bear contempt hereditary,
The beggar native honor.
It is the paster lards the brother’s sides,
The want that makes him lean. Who dares? Who dares
In purity of manhood stand upright
And say, “This man’s a flatterer”? If one be,
So are they all; for every grize of fortune
Is smooth’d by that below. The learned pate
Ducks to the golden fool. All’s obliquy;
There’s nothing level in our cursed natures
But direct villainy. Therefore be abhorr’d
All feasts, societies, and throngs of men!
His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains;
Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots!
Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate
With thy most operant poison! What is here?
Gold? Yellow, glittering, precious gold?
No, gods, I am no idle votarist;
Roots, you clear heavens! Thus much of this will make
Black white, foul fair, wrong right,
Base noble, old young, coward valiant.
Ha, you gods! Why this? What this, you gods? Why, this
Will lug your priests and servants from your sides,
Pluck stout men’s pillows from below their heads.
This yellow slave
Will knit and break religions, bless th’ accurs’d,
Make the hoar leprosy ador’d, place thieves,
And give them title, knee, and approbation
With senators on the bench. This is it
That makes the wappen’d widow wed again;
She, whom the spittle-house and ulcerous sores
Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices
To th’ April day again. Come, damn’d earth,
Thou common whore of mankind, that puts odds
Among the rout of nations, I will make thee
Do thy right nature.
Ha? A drum? Th’ art quick,
But yet I’ll bury thee; thou’t go, strong thief,
When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.
Nay, stay thou out for earnest.

scene.stagedir: Enter Alcibiades, with Drum and Fife, in warlike manner, and Phrynia and Timandra.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: What art thou there? Speak.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart,
For showing me again the eyes of man!

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee,
That art thyself a man?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind.
For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,
That I might love thee something.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I know thee well;
But in thy fortunes am unlearn’d and strange.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I know thee too, and more than that I know thee
I not desire to know. Follow thy drum,
With man’s blood paint the ground, gules, gules,
Religious canons, civil laws are cruel;
Then what should war be? This fell whore of thine
Hath in her more destruction than thy sword,
For all her cherubin look.

speech.speaker: PHRY.
speech.line: Thy lips rot off!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I will not kiss thee, then the rot returns
To thine own lips again.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: How came the noble Timon to this change?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: As the moon does, by wanting light to give:
But then renew I could not, like the moon;
There were no suns to borrow of.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Noble Timon,
What friendship may I do thee?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: None, but to
Maintain my opinion.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: What is it, Timon?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Promise me friendship, but perform none. If thou wilt not promise, the gods plague thee, for thou art a man! If thou dost perform, confound thee, for thou art a man!

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I have heard in some sort of thy miseries.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Thou saw’st them, when I had prosperity.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I see them now, then was a blessed time.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: As thine is now, held with a brace of harlots.

speech.speaker: TIMAN.
speech.line: Is this th’ Athenian minion, whom the world
Voic’d so regardfully?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Art thou Timandra?

speech.speaker: TIMAN.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Be a whore still. They love thee not that use thee;
Give them diseases, leaving with thee their lust.
Make use of thy salt hours, season the slaves
For tubs and baths, bring down rose-cheek’d youth
To the tub-fast and the diet.

speech.speaker: TIMAN.
speech.line: Hang thee, monster!

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Pardon him, sweet Timandra, for his wits
Are drown’d and lost in his calamities.
I have but little gold of late, brave Timon,
The want whereof doth daily make revolt
In my penurious band. I have heard, and griev’d,
How cursed Athens, mindless of thy worth,
Forgetting thy great deeds when neighbor states,
But for thy sword and fortune, trod upon them—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I prithee beat thy drum and get thee gone.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I am thy friend, and pity thee, dear Timon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble?
I had rather be alone.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Why, fare thee well;
Here is some gold for thee.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Keep it, I cannot eat it.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: When I have laid proud Athens on a heap—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Warr’st thou ’gainst Athens?

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Ay, Timon, and have cause.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: The gods confound them all in thy conquest,
And thee after, when thou hast conquer’d!

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Why me, Timon?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: That by killing of villains
Thou wast born to conquer my country.
Put up thy gold. Go on—here’s gold—go on;
Be as a planetary plague when Jove
Will o’er some high-vic’d city hang his poison
In the sick air. Let not thy sword skip one.
Pity not honor’d age for his white beard,
He is an usurer. Strike me the counterfeit matron,
It is her habit only that is honest,
Herself’s a bawd. Let not the virgin’s cheek
Make soft thy trenchant sword; for those milk paps,
That through the window-bars bore at men’s eyes,
Are not within the leaf of pity writ,
But set them down horrible traitors. Spare not the babe,
Whose dimpled smiles from fools exhaust their mercy;
Think it a bastard, whom the oracle
Hath doubtfully pronounc’d the throat shall cut,
And mince it sans remorse. Swear against objects,
Put armor on thine ears and on thine eyes,
Whose proof nor yells of mothers, maids, nor babes,
Nor sight of priests in holy vestments bleeding,
Shall pierce a jot. There’s gold to pay thy soldiers,
Make large confusion; and thy fury spent,
Confounded be thyself! Speak not, be gone.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Hast thou gold yet? I’ll take the gold thou givest me,
Not all thy counsel.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Dost thou, or dost thou not, heaven’s curse upon thee!

speech.speaker: BOTH PHRY. AND TIMAN.
speech.line: Give us some gold, good Timon; hast thou more?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Enough to make a whore forswear her trade,
And to make whores, a bawd. Hold up, you sluts,
Your aprons mountant. You are not oathable,
Although I know You’ll swear, terribly swear
Into strong shudders and to heavenly agues
Th’ immortal gods that hear you. Spare your oaths;
I’ll trust to your conditions, be whores still.
And he whose pious breath seeks to convert you,
Be strong in whore, allure him, burn him up,
Let your close fire predominate his smoke,
And be no turncoats; yet may your pains six months
Be quite contrary. And thatch your poor thin roofs
With burdens of the dead—some that were hang’d,
No matter; wear them, betray with them. Whore still,
Paint till a horse may mire upon your face:
A pox of wrinkles!

speech.speaker: BOTH PHRY. AND TIMAN.
speech.line: Well, more gold—what then?
Believe’t that we’ll do any thing for gold.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Consumptions sow
In hollow bones of man, strike their sharp shins,
And mar men’s spurring. Crack the lawyer’s voice,
That he may never more false title plead,
Nor sound his quillets shrilly; hoar the flamen,
That scolds against the quality of flesh
And not believes himself. Down with the nose,
Down with it flat; take the bridge quite away
Of him that, his particular to foresee,
Smells from the general weal. Make curl’d-pate ruffians bald,
And let the unscarr’d braggarts of the war
Derive some pain from you. Plague all,
That your activity may defeat and quell
The source of all erection. There’s more gold.
Do you damn others, and let this damn you,
And ditches grave you all!

speech.speaker: BOTH PHRY. AND TIMAN.
speech.line: More counsel with more money, bounteous Timon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: More whore, more mischief first; I have given you earnest.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Strike up the drum towards Athens! Farewell, Timon!
If I thrive well, I’ll visit thee again.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: If I hope well, I’ll never see thee more.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: I never did thee harm.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Yes, thou spok’st well of me.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Call’st thou that harm?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Men daily find it. Get thee away, and take
Thy beagles with thee.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: We but offend him. Strike!

scene.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt Alcibiades, Phrynia, and Timandra.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: That nature being sick of man’s unkindness
Should yet be hungry! Common mother, thou
Whose womb unmeasurable and infinite breast
Teems and feeds all; whose self-same mettle,
Whereof thy proud child (arrogant man) is puff’d,
Engenders the black toad and adder blue,
The gilded newt and eyeless venom’d worm,
With all th’ abhorred births below crisp heaven
Whereon Hyperion’s quick’ning fire doth shine:
Yield him who all the human sons do hate,
From forth thy plenteous bosom, one poor root!
Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb,
Let it no more bring out ingrateful man!
Go great with tigers, dragons, wolves, and bears,
Teem with new monsters, whom thy upward face
Hath to the marbled mansion all above
Never presented!—O, a root, dear thanks!—
Dry up thy marrows, vines, and plough-torn leas,
Whereof ingrateful man, with liquorish draughts
And morsels unctious, greases his pure mind,
That from it all consideration slips—
More man? Plague, plague!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I was directed hither. Men report
Thou dost affect my manners, and dost use them.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: ’Tis then, because thou dost not keep a dog,
Whom I would imitate. Consumption catch thee!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: This is in thee a nature but infected,
A poor unmanly melancholy sprung
From change of future. Why this spade? This place?
This slave-like habit? And these looks of care?
Thy flatterers yet wear silk, drink wine, lie soft,
Hug their diseas’d perfumes, and have forgot
That ever Timon was. Shame not these woods
By putting on the cunning of a carper.
Be thou a flatterer now, and seek to thrive
By that which has undone thee; hinge thy knee,
And let his very breath whom thou’lt observe
Blow off thy cap; praise his most vicious strain,
And call it excellent. Thou wast told thus;
Thou gav’st thine ears (like tapsters that bade welcome)
To knaves and all approachers. ’Tis most just
That thou turn rascal; hadst thou wealth again,
Rascals should have’t. Do not assume my likeness.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Were I like thee, I’d throw away myself.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thou hast cast away thyself, being like thyself,
A madman so long, now a fool. What, think’st
That the bleak air, thy boisterous chamberlain,
Will put thy shirt on warm? Will these moist trees,
That have outliv’d the eagle, page thy heels
And skip when thou point’st out? Will the cold brook,
Candied with ice, caudle thy morning taste
To cure thy o’ernight’s surfeit? Call the creatures
Whose naked natures live in all the spite
Of wreakful heaven, whose bare unhoused trunks,
To the conflicting elements expos’d,
Answer mere nature; bid them flatter thee.
O, thou shalt find—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: A fool of thee. Depart.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I love thee better now than e’er I did.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I hate thee worse.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Thou flatter’st misery.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I flatter not, but say thou art a caitiff.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Why dost thou seek me out?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: To vex thee.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Always a villain’s office, or a fool’s.
Dost please thyself in’t?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What, a knave too?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: If thou didst put this sour cold habit on
To castigate thy pride, ’twere well; but thou
Dost it enforcedly. Thou’dst courtier be again,
Wert thou not beggar. Willing misery
Outlives incertain pomp, is crown’d before:
The one is filling still, never complete;
The other, at high wish. Best state, contentless,
Hath a distracted and most wretched being,
Worse than the worst, content.
Thou shouldst desire to die, being miserable.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Not by his breath that is more miserable.
Thou art a slave, whom Fortune’s tender arm
With favor never clasp’d, but bred a dog.
Hadst thou like us from our first swath proceeded
The sweet degrees that this brief world affords
To such as may the passive drugs of it
Freely command, thou wouldst have plung’d thyself
In general riot, melted down thy youth
In different beds of lust, and never learn’d
The icy precepts of respect, but followed
The sug’red game before thee. But myself,
Who had the world as my confectionary,
The mouths, the tongues, the eyes, and hearts of men
At duty, more than I could frame employment;
That numberless upon me stuck as leaves
Do on the oak, have with one winter’s brush
Fell from their boughs, and left me open, bare,
For every storm that blows—I to bear this,
That never knew but better, is some burden:
Thy nature did commence in sufferance, time
Hath made thee hard in’t. Why shouldst thou hate men?
They never flatter’d thee. What hast thou given?
If thou wilt curse, thy father (that poor rag)
Must be thy subject, who in spite put stuff
To some she-beggar and compounded thee
Poor rogue hereditary. Hence, be gone!
If thou hadst not been born the worst of men,
Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Art thou proud yet?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ay, that I am not thee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I, that I was
No prodigal.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I, that I am one now.
Were all the wealth I have shut up in thee,
I’ld give thee leave to hang it. Get thee gone.
That the whole life of Athens were in this!
Thus would I eat it.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Here, I will mend thy feast.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: First mend my company, take away thyself.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: So I shall mend mine own, by th’ lack of thine.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: ’Tis not well mended so, it is but botch’d;
If not, I would it were.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: What wouldst thou have to Athens?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Thee thither in a whirlwind. If thou wilt,
Tell them there I have gold; look, so I have.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Here is no use for gold.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: The best, and truest;
For here it sleeps, and does no hired harm.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Where liest a’ nights, Timon?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Under that’s above me.
Where feed’st thou a’ days, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Where my stomach finds meat, or, rather, where I eat it.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Would poison were obedient and knew my mind!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Where wouldst thou send it?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: To sauce thy dishes.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: The middle of humanity thou never knewest, but the extremity of both ends. When thou wast in thy gilt and thy perfume, they mock’d thee for too much curiosity; in thy rags thou know’st none, but art despis’d for the contrary. There’s a medlar for thee, eat it.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: On what I hate I feed not.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Dost hate a medlar?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ay, though it look like thee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: And th’ hadst hated meddlers sooner, thou shouldst have lov’d thyself better now. What man didst thou ever know unthrift that was belov’d after his means?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Who, without those means thou talk’st of, didst thou ever know belov’d?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Myself.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I understand thee: thou hadst some means to keep a dog.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: What things in the world canst thou nearest compare to thy flatterers?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Women nearest, but men—men are the things themselves. What wouldst thou do with the world, Apemantus, if it lay in thy power?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Give it the beasts, to be rid of the men.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Wouldst thou have thyself fall in the confusion of men, and remain a beast with the beasts?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ay, Timon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: A beastly ambition, which the gods grant thee t’ attain to! If thou wert the lion, the fox would beguile thee; if thou wert the lamb, the fox would eat thee; if thou wert the fox, the lion would suspect thee, when peradventure thou wert accus’d by the ass; if thou wert the ass, thy dullness would torment thee, and still thou liv’dst but as a breakfast to the wolf; if thou wert the wolf, thy greediness would afflict thee, and oft thou shouldst hazard thy life for thy dinner; wert thou the unicorn, pride and wrath would confound thee and make thine own self the conquest of thy fury; wert thou a bear, thou wouldst be kill’d by the horse; wert thou a horse, thou wouldst be seiz’d by the leopard; wert thou a leopard, thou wert germane to the lion, and the spots of thy kindred were jurors on thy life; all thy safety were remotion and thy defense absence. What beast couldst thou be, that were not subject to a beast? And what a beast art thou already, that seest not thy loss in transformation!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: If thou couldst please me with speaking to me, thou mightst have hit upon it here. The commonwealth of Athens is become a forest of beasts.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: How has the ass broke the wall, that thou art out of the city?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Yonder comes a poet and a painter; the plague of company light upon thee! I will fear to catch it, and give way. When I know not what else to do, I’ll see thee again.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: When there is nothing living but thee, thou shalt be welcome. I had rather be a beggar’s dog than Apemantus.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: A plague on thee, thou art too bad to curse!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: All villains that do stand by thee are pure.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: There is no leprosy but what thou speak’st.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: If I name thee.
I’ll beat thee, but I should infect my hands.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: I would my tongue could rot them off!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Away, thou issue of a mangy dog!
Choler does kill me that thou art alive;
I swound to see thee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Would thou wouldst burst!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Away, thou tedious rogue!
I am sorry I shall lose a stone by thee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Beast!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Slave!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Toad!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Rogue, rogue, rogue!
I am sick of this false world, and will love nought
But even the mere necessities upon’t.
Then, Timon, presently prepare thy grave;
Lie where the light foam of the sea may beat
Thy grave-stone daily; make thine epitaph,
That death in me at others’ lives may laugh.
O thou sweet king-killer, and dear divorce
’Twixt natural son and sire! Thou bright defiler
Of Hymen’s purest bed! Thou valiant Mars!
Thou ever young, fresh, lov’d, and delicate wooer,
Whose blush doth thaw the consecrated snow
That lies on Dian’s lap! Thou visible god,
That sold’rest close impossibilities,
And mak’st them kiss! That speak’st with every tongue
To every purpose! O thou touch of hearts,
Think thy slave man rebels, and by thy virtue
Set them into confounding odds, that beasts
May have the world in empire!

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Would ’twere so!
But not till I am dead. I’ll say th’ hast gold;
Thou wilt be throng’d to shortly.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Throng’d to?

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Thy back, I prithee.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: Live, and love thy misery.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Long live so, and so die. I am quit.

speech.speaker: APEM.
speech.line: More things like men! Eat, Timon, and abhor them.

speech.speaker: 1. BAN.
speech.line: Where should he have this gold? It is some poor fragment, some slender ort of his remainder. The mere want of gold, and the falling-from of his friends, drove him into this melancholy.

speech.speaker: 2. BAN.
speech.line: It is nois’d he hath a mass of treasure.

speech.speaker: 3. BAN.
speech.line: Let us make the assay upon him. If he care not for’t, he will supply us easily; if he covetously reserve it, how shall ’s get it?

speech.speaker: 2. BAN.
speech.line: True; for he bears it not about him, ’tis hid.

speech.speaker: 1. BAN.
speech.line: Is not this he?

speech.speaker: ALL OTHER BAN.
speech.line: Where?

speech.speaker: 2. BAN.
speech.line: ’Tis his description.

speech.speaker: 3. BAN.
speech.line: He; I know him.

speech.speaker: ALL OTHER BAN.
speech.line: ’Save thee, Timon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Now, thieves?

speech.speaker: ALL OTHER BAN.
speech.line: Soldiers, not thieves.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Both too, and women’s sons.

speech.speaker: ALL BAN.
speech.line: We are not thieves, but men that much do want.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Your greatest want is, you want much of meat.
Why should you want? Behold, the earth hath roots;
Within this mile break forth a hundred springs;
The oaks bear mast, the briers scarlet heps;
The bounteous huswife Nature on each bush
Lays her full mess before you. Want? Why want?

speech.speaker: 1. BAN.
speech.line: We cannot live on grass, on berries, water,
As beasts and birds and fishes.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Nor on the beasts themselves, the birds and fishes;
You must eat men. Yet thanks I must you con
That you are thieves profess’d, that you work not
In holier shapes; for there is boundless theft
In limited professions. Rascal thieves,
Here’s gold. Go, suck the subtle blood o’ th’ grape,
Till the high fever seethe your blood to froth,
And so scape hanging. Trust not the physician,
His antidotes are poison, and he slays
More than you rob. Take wealth and lives together,
Do, villains, do, since you protest to do’t.
Like workmen, I’ll example you with thievery:
The sun’s a thief, and with his great attraction
Robs the vast sea; the moon’s an arrant thief,
And her pale fire she snatches from the sun;
The sea’s a thief, whose liquid surge resolves
The moon into salt tears; the earth’s a thief,
That feeds and breeds by a composture stol’n
From gen’ral excrement; each thing’s a thief.
The laws, your curb and whip, in their rough power
Has uncheck’d theft. Love not yourselves, away,
Rob one another. There’s more gold. Cut throats,
All that you meet are thieves. To Athens go,
Break open shops; nothing can you steal
But thieves do lose it. Steal less for this I give you,
And gold confound you howsoe’er! Amen.

speech.speaker: 3. BAN.
speech.line: H’as almost charm’d me from my profession, by persuading me to it.

speech.speaker: 1. BAN.
speech.line: ’Tis in the malice of mankind that he thus advises us, not to have us thrive in our mystery.

speech.speaker: 2. BAN.
speech.line: I’ll believe him as an enemy, and give over my trade.

speech.speaker: 1. BAN.
speech.line: Let us first see peace in Athens. There is no time so miserable but a man may be true.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Steward Flavius to Timon.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: O you gods!
Is yond despis’d and ruinous man my lord?
Full of decay and failing? O monument
And wonder of good deeds evilly bestow’d!
What an alteration of honor has desp’rate want made!
What vilder thing upon the earth than friends,
Who can bring noblest minds to basest ends!
How rarely does it meet with this time’s guise,
When man was wish’d to love his enemies!
Grant I may ever love, and rather woo
Those that would mischief me than those that do!
H’as caught me in his eye, I will present
My honest grief unto him; and as my lord,
Still serve him with my life. My dearest master!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Away! What art thou?

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Have you forgot me, sir?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Why dost ask that? I have forgot all men.
Then, if thou grant’st th’ art a man, I have forgot thee.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: An honest poor servant of yours.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Then I know thee not.
I never had honest man about me, I; all
I kept were knaves, to serve in meat to villains.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: The gods are witness,
Nev’r did poor steward wear a truer grief
For his undone lord than mine eyes for you.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: What, dost thou weep? Come nearer. Then I love thee,
Because thou art a woman, and disclaim’st
Flinty mankind, whose eyes do never give
But thorough lust and laughter. Pity’s sleeping:
Strange times, that weep with laughing, not with weeping!

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: I beg of you to know me, good my lord,
T’ accept my grief, and whilst this poor wealth lasts
To entertain me as your steward still.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Had I a steward
So true, so just, and now so comfortable?
It almost turns my dangerous nature wild.
Let me behold thy face. Surely, this man
Was born of woman.
Forgive my general and exceptless rashness,
You perpetual-sober gods! I do proclaim
One honest man—mistake me not, but one;
No more, I pray—and he’s a steward.
How fain would I have hated all mankind,
And thou redeem’st thyself. But all, save thee,
I fell with curses.
Methinks thou art more honest now than wise;
For, by oppressing and betraying me,
Thou mightst have sooner got another service;
For many so arrive at second masters,
Upon their first lord’s neck. But tell me true
(For I must ever doubt, though ne’er so sure),
Is not thy kindness subtle, covetous,
If not a usuring kindness, and, as rich men deal gifts,
Expecting in return twenty for one?

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: No, my most worthy master, in whose breast
Doubt and suspect, alas, are plac’d too late;
You should have fear’d false times when you did feast:
Suspect still comes where an estate is least.
That which I show, heaven knows, is merely love,
Duty, and zeal to your unmatched mind,
Care of your food and living; and believe it,
My most honor’d lord,
For any benefit that points to me,
Either in hope or present, I’d exchange
For this one wish, that you had power and wealth
To requite me by making rich yourself.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Look thee, ’tis so. Thou singly honest man,
Here, take; the gods out of my misery
Has sent thee treasure. Go, live rich and happy,
But thus condition’d: thou shalt build from men;
Hate all, curse all, show charity to none,
But let the famish’d flesh slide from the bone
Ere thou relieve the beggar. Give to dogs
What thou deniest to men. Let prisons swallow ’em,
Debts wither ’em to nothing; be men like blasted woods,
And may diseases lick up their false bloods!
And so farewell and thrive.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: O, let me stay,
And comfort you, my master.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: If thou hat’st curses,
Stay not; fly, whilst thou art blest and free.
Ne’er see thou man, and let me ne’er see thee.

scene.scenedescription: The poet and the painter, having heard that Timon is distributing gold, come to get their share. Timon overhears them plotting about how they will flatter him. Though he pretends to find them honest, when he gives them gold he beats them for villainy. Flavius leads two Senators to Timon’s cave, warning them that there’s no hope of a good welcome, but the Senators insist, since they have promised the Athenians. They tell Timon that the people of Athens want him to return and to run the city, in the hopes that he will be able to save it from Alcibiades. But Timon, after getting their hopes up, informs them that he does not care in the slightest what happens to Athens, and tells them that they should all go hang themselves. The Senators return to Athens to work out how else to save themselves.
scene.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; Timon watching them from his cave.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: As I took note of the place, it cannot be far
Where he abides.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: What’s to be thought of him?
Does the rumor hold for true that he’s
So full of gold?

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Certain. Alcibiades reports it;
Phrynia and Timandra had gold of him.
He likewise enrich’d poor straggling soldiers with
Great quantity. ’Tis said he gave unto
His steward a mighty sum.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Then this breaking of his
Has been but a try for his friends?

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Nothing else.
You shall see him a palm in Athens again, and flourish
With the highest. Therefore, ’tis not amiss
We tender our loves to him in this suppos’d
Distress of his; it will show honestly in us,
And is very likely to load our purposes
With what they travail for, if it be
A just and true report that goes of his having.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: What have you now to present unto him?

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Nothing at this time but my visitation;
Only I will promise him an excellent piece.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: I must serve him so too: tell him of an intent
That’s coming toward him.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Good as the best.
Promising is the very air o’ th’ time;
It opens the eyes of expectation.
Performance is ever the duller for his act,
And but in the plainer and simpler kind of people
The deed of saying is quite out of use.
To promise is most courtly and fashionable;
Performance is a kind of will or testament
Which argues a great sickness in his judgment
That makes it.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Excellent workman! Thou canst not paint a man
So bad as is thyself.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: I am thinking
What I shall say I have provided for him.
It must be a personating of himself;
A satire against the softness of prosperity,
With a discovery of the infinite flatteries
That follow youth and opulency.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Must thou needs
Stand for a villain in thine own work?
Wilt thou whip thine own faults in other men?
Do so, I have gold for thee.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Nay, let’s seek him:
Then do we sin against our own estate,
When we may profit meet, and come too late.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: True:
When the day serves, before black-corner’d night,
Find what thou want’st by free and offer’d light.
Come.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I’ll meet you at the turn. What a god’s gold
That he is worshipp’d in a baser temple
Than where swine feed!
’Tis thou that rig’st the bark and plough’st the foam,
Settlest admired reverence in a slave.
To thee be worship, and thy saints for aye
Be crown’d with plagues, that thee alone obey!
Fit I meet them.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Hail, worthy Timon!

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: Our late noble master!

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Have I once liv’d to see two honest men?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Sir,
Having often of your open bounty tasted,
Hearing you were retir’d, your friends fall’n off,
Whose thankless natures (O abhorred spirits!)
Not all the whips of heaven are large enough—
What, to you,
Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence
To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover
The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude
With any size of words.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Let it go naked, men may see’t the better.
You that are honest, by being what you are
Make them best seen and known.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: He and myself
Have travail’d in the great show’r of your gifts,
And sweetly felt it.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ay, you are honest men.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: We are hither come to offer you our service.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you?
Can you eat roots and drink cold water? No?

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: What we can do, we’ll do, to do you service.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Y’ are honest men; y’ have heard that I have gold,
I am sure you have. Speak truth, y’ are honest men.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: So it is said, my noble lord, but therefore
Came not my friend nor I.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Good honest men! Thou draw’st a counterfeit
Best in all Athens; th’ art indeed the best,
Thou counterfeit’st most lively.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: So, so, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: E’en so, sir, as I say.—And, for thy fiction,
Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth
That thou art even natural in thine art.
But for all this, my honest-natur’d friends,
I must needs say you have a little fault;
Marry, ’tis not monstrous in you, neither wish I
You take much pains to mend.

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: Beseech your honor
To make it known to us.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You’ll take it ill.

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: Most thankfully, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Will you indeed?

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: Doubt it not, worthy lord.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: There’s never a one of you but trusts a knave
That mightily deceives you.

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: Do we, my lord?

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Ay, and you hear him cog, see him dissemble,
Know his gross patchery, love him, feed him,
Keep in your bosom; yet remain assur’d
That he’s a made-up villain.

speech.speaker: PAIN.
speech.line: I know none such, my lord.

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Look you, I love you well, I’ll give you gold,
Rid me these villains from your companies;
Hang them, or stab them, drown them in a draught,
Confound them by some course, and come to me,
I’ll give you gold enough.

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: Name them, my lord, let’s know them.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You that way and you this; but two in company;
Each man apart, all single and alone,
Yet an arch-villain keeps him company.
If where thou art, two villains shall not be,
Come not near him.
If thou wouldst not reside
But where one villain is, then him abandon.—
Hence, pack! There’s gold; you came for gold, ye slaves.
You have work for me; there’s payment, hence!
You are an alcumist, make gold of that.
Out, rascal dogs!

scene.stagedir: Exeunt both, driven out by Timon, who retires to his cave.
Enter Steward Flavius and two Senators.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: It is vain that you would speak with Timon;
For he is set so only to himself,
That nothing but himself which looks like man
Is friendly with him.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Bring us to his cave.
It is our part and promise to th’ Athenians
To speak with Timon.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: At all times alike
Men are not still the same; ’twas time and griefs
That fram’d him thus. Time with his fairer hand,
Offering the fortunes of his former days,
The former man may make him. Bring us to him,
And chance it as it may.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Here is his cave.
Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon,
Look out and speak to friends. Th’ Athenians
By two of their most reverend Senate greet thee.
Speak to them, noble Timon.

scene.stagedir: Enter Timon out of his cave.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Thou sun that comforts, burn! Speak and be hang’d.
For each true word, a blister, and each false
Be as a cantherizing to the root o’ th’ tongue,
Consuming it with speaking!

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Worthy Timon—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Of none but such as you, and you of Timon.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: The senators of Athens greet thee, Timon.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I thank them, and would send them back the plague,
Could I but catch it for them.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: O, forget
What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.
The senators with one consent of love
Entreat thee back to Athens, who have thought
On special dignities, which vacant lie,
For thy best use and wearing.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: They confess
Toward thee forgetfulness too general gross;
Which now the public body, which doth seldom
Play the recanter, feeling in itself
A lack of Timon’s aid, hath sense withal
Of it own fall, restraining aid to Timon,
And send forth us to make their sorrowed render,
Together with a recompense more fruitful
Than their offense can weigh down by the dram;
Ay, even such heaps and sums of love and wealth
As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs,
And write in thee the figures of their love,
Ever to read them thine.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: You witch me in it;
Surprise me to the very brink of tears.
Lend me a fool’s heart and a woman’s eyes,
And I’ll beweep these comforts, worthy senators.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Therefore so please thee to return with us,
And of our Athens, thine and ours, to take
The captainship, thou shalt be met with thanks,
Allow’d with absolute power, and thy good name
Live with authority; so soon we shall drive back
Of Alcibiades th’ approaches wild,
Who, like a boar too savage, doth root up
His country’s peace.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: And shakes his threat’ning sword
Against the walls of Athens.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Therefore, Timon—

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Well, sir, I will; therefore I will, sir, thus:
If Alcibiades kill my countrymen,
Let Alcibiades know this of Timon,
That Timon cares not. But if he sack fair Athens,
And take our goodly aged men by th’ beards,
Giving our holy virgins to the stain
Of contumelious, beastly, mad-brain’d war,
Then let him know, and tell him Timon speaks it,
In pity of our aged and our youth,
I cannot choose but tell him that I care not,
And let him take’t at worst—for their knives care not,
While you have throats to answer. For myself,
There’s not a whittle in th’ unruly camp
But I do prize it at my love before
The reverend’st throat in Athens. So I leave you
To the protection of the prosperous gods,
As thieves to keepers.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Stay not, all’s in vain.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Why, I was writing of my epitaph;
It will be seen tomorrow. My long sickness
Of health and living now begins to mend,
And nothing brings me all things. Go, live still;
Be Alcibiades your plague, you his,
And last so long enough!

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: We speak in vain.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: But yet I love my country, and am not
One that rejoices in the common wrack,
As common bruit doth put it.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: That’s well spoke.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Commend me to my loving countrymen—

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: These words become your lips as they pass thorough them.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: And enter in our ears like great triumphers
In their applauding gates.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Commend me to them,
And tell them that, to ease them of their griefs,
Their fears of hostile strokes, their aches, losses,
Their pangs of love, with other incident throes
That nature’s fragile vessel doth sustain
In life’s uncertain voyage, I will some kindness do them:
I’ll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades’ wrath.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: I like this well, he will return again.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: I have a tree, which grows here in my close,
That mine own use invites me to cut down,
And shortly must I fell it. Tell my friends,
Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree,
From high to low throughout, that whoso please
To stop affliction, let him take his haste,
Come hither, ere my tree hath felt the axe,
And hang himself. I pray you do my greeting.

speech.speaker: FLAV.
speech.line: Trouble him no further, thus you still shall find him.

speech.speaker: TIM.
speech.line: Come not to me again, but say to Athens,
Timon hath made his everlasting mansion
Upon the beached verge of the salt flood,
Who once a day with his embossed froth
The turbulent surge shall cover; thither come,
And let my grave-stone be your oracle.
Lips, let four words go by and language end!
What is amiss, plague and infection mend!
Graves only be men’s works, and death their gain!
Sun, hide thy beams, Timon hath done his reign.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: His discontents are unremovably
Coupled to nature.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: Our hope in him is dead. Let us return,
And strain what other means is left unto us
In our dear peril.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: It requires swift foot.

scene.scenedescription: The other Senators wait to find out if Timon will return. They hear that Alcibiades too has tried to recruit him. The two who went to see Timon return and report their failure.
scene.stagedir: Enter two other Senators with a Messenger.

speech.speaker: 3. SEN.
speech.line: Thou hast painfully discover’d; are his files
As full as thy report?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: I have spoke the least.
Besides, his expedition promises
Present approach.

speech.speaker: 4. SEN.
speech.line: We stand much hazard if they bring not Timon.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: I met a courier, one mine ancient friend,
Whom, though in general part we were oppos’d,
Yet our old love made a particular force,
And made us speak like friends. This man was riding
From Alcibiades to Timon’s cave
With letters of entreaty, which imported
His fellowship i’ th’ cause against your city,
In part for his sake mov’d.

speech.speaker: 3. SEN.
speech.line: Here come our brothers.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: No talk of Timon, nothing of him expect.
The enemy’s drum is heard, and fearful scouring
Doth choke the air with dust. In, and prepare:
Ours is the fall, I fear, our foes the snare.

scene.scenelocation: The woods. A rude tomb near Timon’s cave.
scene.stagedir: Enter a Soldier in the woods, seeking Timon. A rude tomb seen.

speech.speaker: SOLD.
speech.line: By all description this should be the place.
Who’s here? Speak ho! No answer? What is this?

line.recite: “Timon is dead, who hath outstretch’d his span:
Some beast read this; there does not live a man.”

speech.line: Dead, sure, and this his grave. What’s on this tomb
I cannot read; the character I’ll take with wax;
Our captain hath in every figure skill,
An ag’d interpreter, though young in days.
Before proud Athens he’s set down by this,
Whose fall the mark of his ambition is.

scene.scenedescription: Alcibiades and is army arrive before Athens, and he gives them one last chance to surrender. They plead with him to be merciful and agree to yield if he will promise to. Alcibiades agrees, promising to punish only his own enemies and Timon’s, and letting the Athenians decide who the latter are. The soldier brings the news that Timon has died, leaving one last curse on his grave. Alcibiades grieves.
scene.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter Alcibiades with his powers before Athens.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Sound to this coward and lascivious town
Our terrible approach.
speech.stagedir: The Senators appear upon the walls.
speech.line: Till now you have gone on and fill’d the time
With all licentious measure, making your wills
The scope of justice; till now myself and such
As slept within the shadow of your power
Have wander’d with our travers’d arms, and breath’d
Our sufferance vainly. Now the time is flush,
When crouching marrow in the bearer strong
Cries (of itself) “No more!” Now breathless wrong
Shall sit and pant in your great chairs of ease,
And pursy insolence shall break his wind
With fear and horrid flight.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Noble and young—
When thy first griefs were but a mere conceit,
Ere thou hadst power or we had cause of fear,
We sent to thee to give thy rages balm,
To wipe out our ingratitude with loves
Above their quantity.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: So did we woo
Transformed Timon to our city’s love
By humble message and by promis’d means.
We were not all unkind, nor all deserve
The common stroke of war.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: These walls of ours
Were not erected by their hands from whom
You have receiv’d your grief; nor are they such
That these great tow’rs, trophies, and schools should fall
For private faults in them.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: Nor are they living
Who were the motives that you first went out;
Shame, that they wanted cunning in excess,
Hath broke their hearts. March, noble lord,
Into our city with thy banners spread;
By decimation, and a tithed death,
If thy revenges hunger for that food
Which nature loathes, take thou the destin’d tenth,
And by the hazard of the spotted die
Let die the spotted.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: All have not offended;
For those that were, it is not square to take
On those that are, revenge; crimes, like lands,
Are not inherited. Then, dear countryman,
Bring in thy ranks, but leave without thy rage;
Spare thy Athenian cradle and those kin
Which in the bluster of thy wrath must fall
With those that have offended; like a shepherd,
Approach the fold and cull th’ infected forth,
But kill not all together.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: What thou wilt,
Thou rather shalt enforce it with thy smile
Than hew to’t with thy sword.

speech.speaker: 1. SEN.
speech.line: Set but thy foot
Against our rampir’d gates and they shall ope,
So thou wilt send thy gentle heart before,
To say thou’t enter friendly.

speech.speaker: 2. SEN.
speech.line: Throw thy glove,
Or any token of thine honor else,
That thou wilt use the wars as thy redress
And not as our confusion, all thy powers
Shall make their harbor in our town till we
Have seal’d thy full desire.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Then there’s my glove;
Descend, and open your uncharged ports.
Those enemies of Timon’s and mine own
Whom you yourselves shall set out for reproof
Fall, and no more; and to atone your fears
With my more noble meaning, not a man
Shall pass his quarter, or offend the stream
Of regular justice in your city’s bounds,
But shall be remedied to your public laws
At heaviest answer.

speech.speaker: BOTH.
speech.line: ’Tis most nobly spoken.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.
speech.line: Descend, and keep your words.

scene.stagedir: The Senators descend and open the gates.

speech.speaker: SOLD.
speech.line: My noble general, Timon is dead,
Entomb’d upon the very hem o’ th’ sea,
And on his grave-stone this insculpture, which
With wax I brought away, whose soft impression
Interprets for my poor ignorance.

speech.speaker: ALCIB.

line.recite: “Here lies a wretched corse, of wretched soul bereft;
Seek not my name: a plague consume you, wicked caitiffs left!
Here lie I, Timon, who, alive, all living men did hate;
Pass by and curse thy fill, but pass and stay not here thy gait.”

speech.line: These well express in thee thy latter spirits:
Though thou abhorr’dst in us our human griefs,
Scorn’dst our brains’ flow, and those our droplets which
From niggard nature fall, yet rich conceit
Taught thee to make vast Neptune weep for aye
On thy low grave, on faults forgiven. Dead
Is noble Timon, of whose memory
Hereafter more. Bring me into your city,
And I will use the olive with my sword:
Make war breed peace, make peace stint war, make each
Prescribe to other as each other’s leech.
Let our drums strike.
